NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods, ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return plus is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Ottawa, January 4, 1938.

Dear Sir:

On the above Requisition there was ordered asbestos slate blackboard with necessary chalk trough and moulding 40' long by 3½' wide.

A letter dated December 21/37 from the Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Residential School reads in part as follows:

"The blackboards arrived a few days ago but in a damaged condition. Five pieces, totalling a weight of 400 lbs., were packed in a light frame and were all broken. They are unfit for use as each piece is cracked from top to bottom."

The above blackboards are urgently required at the St. Mary's Mission Residential School and I would therefore appreciate if you would take up the matter with the firm who supplied this blackboard and arrange with them to forward new blackboards at once. It will be advisable to point out to them that we have received several complaints regarding the manner in which the blackboard is packed and, consequently, in shipping new blackboards, it should be shipped in strong frames.

I presume that the firms will replace the damaged blackboards free of charge.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

King's Printer,

Dear Sir:

They have filed a claim with the Canadian Pacific Railway, and they will look after the return of the damaged blackboards.

The matter is therefore considered closed.

Yours truly,

J.W. Driscoll

UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE OBELATE FATHERS

MISSION, B.C.
June 5th, 1940.

Mr. T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

I have recently forwarded through the Indian Agent, the school supplies requisition for the coming year. Acting upon the instructions, contained in your letter of April 13th, I have made a serious effort to list only the school supplies that are essential. The items and the amounts requested have been curtailed to a minimum in an effort to co-operate with the department's desire to keep expenditures as low as possible. Last year it apparently happened that the amounts of several items were considerably reduced by the department with the result that I was obliged to purchase about forty dollars worth of text-books and equipment out of the regular school funds, which are not too plentiful. I do not believe that this is the intention of the department. Although the authorized pupilage for the school is 172, the actual number of pupils is 201 and estimation of the amounts should be based on this number. I would be greatly pleased therefore if an effort were made to supply the amounts and items, listed on the requisition.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.
Ottawa,
July 22, 1940.

Before filling it I thought it advisable to write to you as possibly only part of the requisition has reached this office.

UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE OBLATE FATHERS

MISSION, B.C.
July 25th, 1940.

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Many thanks for your kindness in writing me in regard to the School material requisition. There were only two sheets to our list and the first and last items were the same as noted in your letter. However item #4 calls for 3 gross of scribblers and item #12 for 2 gross of lead pencils. This is according to the copy in the files here and these items should show on the list in your hands.

In my letter of June 5th, I did not intend to give the impression that the school requisition was large. All I wished to insist on was the fact that the items and the amounts on our requisition represented the essential minimum for the current year. I personally supervised the inventory of the supplies on hand before the requisition was made out. It sometimes happens that the amounts are reduced by the department in the thought that the amounts requested are only approximate. This is what I wished to avoid in our case. I might add that the St. Basil's hymn books are a very urgently needed item. I trust that this information will be of help to you and wish to thank you again for taking this matter up with me.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Major J.M. MacKay,

Dear Sir;

I am listing herewith some text-books that are urgently needed in our classrooms. I had been hoping that they would arrive with the shipments from the Department, which have been rather late this year, but apparently they are not coming. For the most part these books are part of the list that Mr. MacKenzie, the school inspector insisted upon. Some we have received, but in insufficient quantities, others have not been received at all. The books are as follows:

1 doz. Happy Days readers for Grade 1B. Ginn & Co., Toronto.
3 doz. Let's Play Pre-primers.
2 doz. Revised Corona Readers Gr.2.
1 doz. Paths of Grace Gr.3.
1 doz. Revised Corona Readers Gr.5
1 doz. Revised Corona Readers Gr.6
3 doz. Pat and Patsy pre-primers. J.M.Dent & Sons, Tor. & Vanc.

The lack of these books is a constant source of discouragement and difficulty to our teachers, who are very competent. As Mr. MacKenzie pointed out, the Indian children are handicapped from the start in language, and, consequently, if we wish to attain good results, they must have very good readers. I am sure that you see this point and will do your utmost to help us, as you have done so many times in the past. We are all well at the school and things are running nicely.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith school material requisition for the coming year. It has taken some time to prepare this list in order to incorporate the recommendations of the Inspector, Mr. Mackenzie. On the first three pages of the requisition, I have listed the texts and articles, which he said were absolutely necessary. These texts are the best and are standard in the Provincial Public Schools. It is essential that we receive them as ordered; there should be a copy for each child especially in regard to readers and workbooks. The texts in Health, Social Studies and Science have been reduced in number, because we can make one text do for two children. The remaining sheets of the requisition cover the ordinary supplies that will be needed for the coming year.

In conformity with the Department's wish, I have ordered only what is deemed necessary and in limited quantities. I would be glad if you would do all in your power to help us obtain the items and texts as ordered. It is so necessary, because most of our text books are quite ancient. This constitutes a handicap, which even the best teaching cannot overcome.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Ottawa, August 6th, 1947.

Dear Father Fleury:

We have received a long requisition from your school recently for school supplies for the academic year 1947-48. This is to inform you that the provision of these supplies may be delayed until sometime in September. The reason for this is that your requisition should have been forwarded to the Department by December 31st, 1946. Your attention is drawn to Item No. 21 of the December issue of the Bulletin. In this Item, principals of residential schools were specially requested to complete and submit to the Department their requisitions for school supplies by the above date. Our records do not indicate that you did so.

We have approximately 300 Indian day school requisitions to be filled every summer, and we cannot handle this number during that time in addition to requisitions from the 76 residential schools; hence the reason for our request for the submission of residential school requisitions by the end of the calendar year.

Yours sincerely,

August 12th, 1947.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Sup't. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Mr. Neary:

I wish to thank you for your letter of August 8th, file #153-1-471, in regard to our school supplies requisition. I regret the delay in forwarding it; the more so, as it was due to a misunderstanding on our part. I had two unfortunate illnesses during the past term and while away in the hospital had left instructions for both the school requisition and the drug requisition to be sent forward. I did not realize that neither of the requisitions had been sent until the end of the term. I quite understand the inconvenience this must cause you and I am very sorry. I have explained the reason for the delay to assure you that it was more an unfortunate error on our part, rather than disregard for your instructions.

I recall that on a visit to your office in January last, you mentioned that it would be in order for me to purchase directly, up to $75.00 worth of science equipment, for the use of the higher grades. We were unable to obtain this equipment at the time and managed to finish the term without it. I would like to know what instructions I should follow in order to obtain the needed equipment for the coming term.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.
Ottawa, September 2nd, 1947.

Dear Father Fleury:

I have for acknowledgement your letter of the 12th instant regarding school supplies.

An order has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office for the supplies requested by you, and these should reach your school in due course.

You may expend the sum of $75.00 in the purchase of science equipment for the use of the higher grades in the St. Mary's Residential School. An account, in duplicate, should be forwarded to the Department when these supplies have been received.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Father Hennessy:

Attached I am returning your requisition for standard text books for your school.

In the meantime, we are forwarding the requisition for supplies to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery for shipping.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Sir,

February 13th, 1896.

July 25, 1896.

Frank Berlin Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

You will be conveying a favor upon us by forwarding the enclosed within the proper authorities.

As you are aware in our anxiety to make this school as efficient as possible we have just completed at considerable expense a large building containing workshops, board-room, instructors' rooms and a couple of dormitories. Unfortunately before this venture could be put into effect all the money we could scrape together so that the disaster of fire was found upon a condition which included all things further building. Fortunately we have fine weather now so that the girls are able to work outside but how it will be in the winter is problematical does not like the space however as it must be faced, and the sooner the better.

I take the liberty of soliciting your good offices in our behalf.

The first thing we did was file a statement our loss before the Insurance Co but were informed that as fire did not occur in either of the main buildings which were alone insured we had no claim, and we can only appeal to the Government.

To rebuild the laundry and bakery and make good machines, utensils and clothing destroyed a sum of $1000 will be required.

Feeling sure that with your usual kindness you will do all in your power for us.

I am

Sincerely Yours,

E. C. Chirouze, O.M.S.

My Lord,

I have the honor to apply to your Lordship for an addition to be connected with the main building of the boys' department at St. Mary's School.

The foundations of our kitchen are too weakly set, and in fact, the whole building is in such a bad condition that a repairing means simply a covering of everything. Moreover, the dining-room 32 x 15 ft. is altogether too small to accommodate our boys or more boys along with from ten to fifteen other persons (teachers and matrons) for whom we other rooms can conveniently be had. A large infirmary, as well as a new convenient and more spacious bath-room are also urgently needed. The room used at present as infirmary is only 12 x 16 ft., which is evidently insufficient; considering the number of pupils and the frequent indispositions of Indian children. With regard to the bath-room, I beg to state that, besides being in a most inconvenient place, where there is no possibility of connection with hot water, it is also extremely small, and in both these respects is most deficient.

All these disadvantages can perfectly be remedied by adding a new wing to the main building. The said new wing, as shown on the plan here with enclosed, will contain a dining-room, a library, a gymnasium, a dormitory, a bath-room, and a wash-room.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott-

The Reverend Father J. Welch of New Westminster, B.C., Supervisor of the Indian work of the Oblate Order in his area, made certain requests during his recent visit to the Department.

In brief, he asked for an outbuilding for the St. Mary's Boarding School at Mission, B.C. to serve as laundry, kitchen and sewing-room. His approximation of the cost is $10,000.00. A new barn to cost $5,000.00 is urgently needed and the same amount is required to enlarge the present building to provide additional classroom, play-room and dormitory space.

You will remember that the Department promised careful consideration in connection with the needs at this school and at the Squamish Boarding School, North Vancouver. I have placed another memorandum on the file of the last named institution.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Improvements suggested:

1- New building consisting of a basement, ground floor, first floor.
   Basement for laundry and cellar,
   Ground floor consisting of one kitchen and pantry,
   four dining rooms.
   First floor: sewing room, linen and clothes room.

2- Alterations:
   In the boys' school:
   Present recreation room to be converted into a class room (giving the Institution two class rooms or if they are united one large, well ventilated class room).
   Present pantry to be used for shower baths and toilet.
   Present kitchen and dining rooms, to be used for recreation room.
   Top story, next to dormitory, in the wing, to be altered into dormitory, will accommodate twenty boys.

   In the girls' school:
   Present kitchen, dining room, to be converted into recreation room for girls, and Indian parlor.
   Present recreation room, to contain shower baths and bath rooms and toilet for girls. Cloak room too.
   Present Indian parlor and room, will be used for hospital purposes.
   Sewing room, converted into dormitory, will accommodate ten children.

3- Advantages:
   Single kitchen:
   Saving labor and expenses.
   Giving the boys more congenial work and placing the girls in their proper place.
   Having a central building, which might be called a technical building, for the girls, discipline will be easier, the work will be more efficient, and the running of the school will be more economical.

   Central building for kitchen (with the existing central furnace) away from main buildings, fire risk greatly lessened.

   More accommodation for pupils will be obtained; ninety children at school at present and some fifteen applications turned down.

   Alterations will provide the children (each side) with a well ventilated, large recreation room, rainy days being numerous, the need of a large recreation room is obvious.

   Better class room
   Cleanliness easily maintained, sanitary condition children will be able to take frequent baths.

   The need of a laundry is obvious.

   The taxes increasing, ways and means to run the school economically and with great efficiency must be found. The above alterations will help.

   We must economize or be compelled to close St. Mary's as an Indian School.

Honourable Sir:

I have come to Ottawa to ask the Indian Department to make certain important improvements in St Mary's Indian School at Mission, B.C., viz:

A—To erect a steam laundry. The washing (for 100 persons) is now done in a shed and all by hand;
B—Above the laundry to build a common kitchen with dining rooms for boys, girls and staff;
C—As a third story (or second story if laundry is put in a basement) a large sewing room which would also serve the purpose of an auditorium for the children's concerts.

B—We have a farm in connection with the school, the produce of which goes to the upkeep of the school children, and yet, this farm land is taxed by the municipality to the extent of about $1,000.00 per annum or nearly one sixth of our per capita grant. We consider that these taxes should be borne by the Indian Department.

C—A barn is urgently needed but the school has no funds with which to erect it, as practically the entire Government grant each year and all the produce of the farm go to the support and education of the Indian children, who after all, are the wards of the Government. Would the Department be willing to vote us $5,000.00 towards a new barn?

D—When I have explained to Mr Duncan C. Scott who has always shown great interest in the welfare of our Indians, how by a small outlay, the class-rooms, play-rooms and dormitories could be enlarged, and provision be easily made for 20 or 30 more pupils.

E—Lastly, I am making an appeal in behalf of the Indian School in North Vancouver. The Department in all fairness should give them additional help or build them a new school. At present the children and the Sisters are packed like the proverbial sardines. For lack of funds they cannot better conditions. As at St Mary's (Mission B.C.) their little garden and orchard are heavily taxed. The per capita grant is barely enough to supply the children and Sisters with food. It is only by appealing to the charity of other institutions that they can make ends meet. These hardworking and self-sacrificing women are the servants of the Government; why should they be forced to beg, in order to be able to carry on their noble work?

a plan to erect a steam laundry, a central kitchen with

at St. Mary's will not be required for many, many years, as

laundry, central kitchen, etc., should I think be taken into

There is a farm and garden at this institution, large enough for a big residential school. All the priests in the vicinity are in favour of this. A small increase in pupilage - say from 84 to 90 - could be offered now. Father Duplanil suggests the principle of having parents pay something to the school; the educational facilities would be more appreciated. New flooring is needed in the girls' playroom and in both dining rooms (boys' and girls' buildings separate). Girls' dormitories should be provided with fire escapes.

In the near future, a special building should be provided (kitchen and 4 dining rooms). Space would then be available for playrooms, infirmaries and showers.

Dear Sir:

1/---To enlarge 10 windows, 5 on each side, in the cows barn (sheet4) and to make them with 9 lights 10x14 instead of four lights.

REASONS FOR ABOVE ALTERATIONS:
We have a very mild climate here at St. Mary's. It rains very frequently. It is dark and cloudy the greater part of the year. Barns need as much light as possible. It is the experience of leading farmers and Experimental Farms in the District. It is recommended in fighting tuberculosis among the cattle.

MANGERS:
6/---To replace the 6 lifting mangers mentioned on page 18 of specifications, by steel divisions, B.T. book, fig. 54 page 5b of new catalog. Specifications call for concrete mangers for 22 stalls. Lifting mangers are unnecessary if steel divisions are used.

Lifting mangers do not last more than four years, the bottom must be replace after a year. Salt eats up the iron and the continual licking by cattle destroys it completely in a very short time. Concrete is more permanent and easier to clean.

Our Method of Mounting the Papec Cutter has Attracted Wide Attention and Won Approval of Farmers Everywhere

The Papec Mounting is strongly constructed of steel channels—there are no wooden parts to twist and warp. There are but few parts, and nothing to get out of order. The Peter Hamilton Mower

The Peter Hamilton Mower is especially well adapted for cutting the hay grown on Canadian farms. It is strong and rigid in every part, has great traction power, is easy to draw and operate and absolutely dependable under all conditions, even the most difficult. Nothing but the best materials are used in its construction, and it is carefully built by competent mechanics.

The Main Frame is very staunch—there are no weak spots in it. The drive wheels are high with broad face. There is no lost motion—when the mower goes forward the knives cut.

The Push Bar is a steel forging made in one piece, especially heavy and stiff, and is connected at front and rear of the main frame as shown in the illustration. This Bar has adjusting nuts at the front end for lining up the bar, or centering the knife. You always have perfect alignment on Peter Hamilton Mowers.
One Piece Main Frame

The Cutter Bar is of Cold Rolled Steel reinforced with a rib running the entire length of the bar, making it strong and rigid enough to ensure a frictionless and smooth running knife. The knife itself is held firmly in place by means of substantial holders and long steel wearing plates against which it runs. These wearing plates are easily replaced when worn and are quite inexpensive.

The Pitman is long and made of best second growth hickory or oak with forged steel jaws at both ends. The Pitman Box is fitted with brass wearing surface and self-acting oil retainers which prevents loss of oil and effectually lubricates the wearing surfaces.

The Tilting Lever can be fixed to give a free adjustment, allowing the guards to adjust themselves automatically to the unevenness of the ground. The guards can be tilted up or down without moving the Cutter Bar backwards or forwards, or out of line with the pitman and frame. A powerful foot lever raises the bar clear of the ground when turning corners, or passing over roots or stones. In raising the bar the outer shoe is raised from the ground first, eliminating all danger of the bar catching on the obstacle. A strong adjustable coil spring, which, as well as assisting the operator in raising the bar also, to a certain extent, carries it on the wheels, thus avoiding considerable friction on the ground, and giving more power for the working parts of the machine.

All Bearings throughout the Mower are either fitted with Roller Bearings or Renewable Frictionless Bearings. The Gears are all accurately made and snugly fitted, so that there is no lost motion. Perfect gears and perfect alignment result in an easy running noiseless machine.

Peter Hamilton Mowers are built in three sizes. Cutter Bars being four and one-half feet, five feet and six feet long. On the six-foot Mower the wheels are larger and farther apart than on the smaller sizes.
No. 4 Steel Rake

Every farmer who has ever used a No. 4 Peter Hamilton Rake, will tell you that this rake not only rakes up a bigger wind row and leaves it clearer after dumping, but that it also cleans up the field better than any other rake. The reasons are, the wheels are high in diameter. The Teeth have a big gather and when dumped, lift clear of the wind-row. They rake clean because the high carbon, oil-tempered teeth are curved to bring them well under the rake, so that they slide along the ground picking up all the hay.

The Frame throughout is heavy angle steel, thoroughly braced and trussed so that there is no danger of the rake ever sagging or becoming twisted.

The Self-Dumping Device is one of the most popular features of this rake; it operates from either wheel, a slight pressure on the Foot Lever being sufficient to throw the dump rods into engagement with the Teeth in each hub, where they are held until the Rake Head is raised to its highest point, and the hay is dropped.

Dumping Rods can be turned end for end, and also interchanged, giving four wears instead of only one.

The Trip Casting, against which the Dump Rod Casting strikes to drop the Teeth, is adjustable to accommodate the height of the dump to heavy or light hay; its action is exactly the same whether turning a corner or raking straight ahead. In all cases the teeth drop closely behind the windrow. In driving a fast walking horse on an ordinary rake, the teeth do not drop quick enough, thereby leaving a strip of unraked hay. You can adjust this difficulty on the No. 4 All Steel Rake to suit the horse (fast or slow).

Another Point. It is possible without wrench or hammer to change the raking position of the Teeth, as it is desirable sometimes to run them higher from the ground. For instance, they should not run as close over wet and boggy ground as over a smooth, dry meadow. Simply by changing the connection, any position of the Teeth can be secured.

In every part it is light, strong and durable, and in case of operation and capacity for work, it has no equal.

The Man with the Silo has The Advantage

The cost of feeding the animals is the greatest expense connected with the livestock and dairying businesses. Experiments conducted by experimental farms over a period of fifteen years have proven silage to be the most economic food for the production of stock and stock products.

During a very severe winter experienced in Western Canada recently, cattle starved to death on the ranges. Hay was hard to get even at ridiculously high prices. Many Western Canada farmers are now erecting silos as insurance against a repetition of such conditions.

Eight times more feed can be stored in the silo than in the mow. A silo saves in storage space. Silage can be carried over from one season to another for several years and still be fed at a profit.

Silage is a succulent, grass-like feed, easily digested, and seems to stimulate digestion. Less sickness is experienced among the stock when silage is fed. Silage stimulates the milk flow, and all milking stock should have it.

Corn silage is the cheapest source of the principal element required by cattle, i.e., digestible carbohydrates. The man with the silo has the advantage over his neighbor without one.

Dear Sir:

I received your letter of August 28th, File 153-1-5, regarding the erection of new building which is required at St. Mary's Indian School.

Some two years ago, shortly after my appointment, I approached the Department about the matter. The Institution had then two kitchens, an old fashion laundry, etc. I wrote about very much needed changes and improvements. The Department was very kind, we have already a new barn.

Since then I find that the accommodations afforded by St. Mary's are not sufficient for the number of children of school age in the District; they are not sufficient for the number of applications I receive every year. This matter has been the subject of a great deal of consideration and discussion. The matter was discussed with Mr. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, at the time of his visit to St. Mary's. After examining the buildings, Mr. Scott agrees with Father Welch and myself, that the best way and therefore the only way is the erection of a new school, large enough to accommodate all the children of the District. This new school is to be erected as soon as possible. Meantime I think that some amelioration in the laundry should be considered at once. The old fashion, back braking laundry of St. Mary's should be equipped with some modern and labor saving devices. I will write more fully on this matter within a few days.

Yours sincerely,

We recently had an enquiry from the Indian Agent at New Westminster, B.C. for School Desks for their Mission School.

Dear Sir,

As you are aware an epidemic of diphtheria has broken out in St. Mary's School Mission.

Last March we had smallpox in the school and seriously felt the necessity of an isolation hospital. Just at the time there happened to be two buildings for sale on our property, two buildings, two houses in fact which were offered to us for the nominal sum of $450. We decided to purchase them for some future emergency. It is well we did so for at this moment they are serving the purpose of an isolation hospital for our little diphtheria patients.

Besides furnishing the buildings we wish also to install electric light and a telephone, so that the trained nurse in charge may be able to communicate with the school or the doctor at any hour of the day or night.
While doing our best for the children we have avoided unnecessary expenditure. About $650 will cover the expenses we have incurred, and I feel sure that Mr. Duncan C. Scott will make us an allowance for this amount. When you have occasion to write him I shall be grateful if you will kindly request him to do us this favor.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

J. Wirth. O.M.I.
Sir,

I have the honour to forward you herewith, a letter which I have received from the Rev. Father Welch, and which is self-explanatory.

There are at the moment, 107 Grant earning pupils in St Mary's School, and in addition, the Fathers invariably carry a number without recompense.

In an institution of this size, outbreaks calling for an isolation hospital, have always to be reckoned with, and I would most strongly recommend that any assistance possible be given the Fathers in meeting the cost of these very necessary buildings.

There are at present seven cases of Diphtheria being cared for in these buildings, and if they were not available, the cost to the Department of Public isolation care, and treatment would probably be in excess of the amount now asked by the Fathers.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Dear Sir:

Permit me to lay before you a situation which, I feel, calls for immediate attention. Both the boys' and the girls' buildings here are without fire escapes of any kind. The buildings are of wood and of three stories and the children sleep on the top floors. If a fire started during the night and got as well under way as before being discovered as fires often do, it is doubtful if one of the fifty odd girls would get out alive and the boys' chances are but little better.

In the case of the girls' building, there is one stairs and it lands in a hall situated near the centre of the building and having no door opening to the outside. The houses are old, dusty, dry and veritable tinder boxes; the electric wiring as of the old-fashioned kind with naked wires; during cold periods in winter, stoves are stoked to full capacity in various rooms; and added to all this, is the ever-present danger of the children setting the house afire purposely. Therefore, the danger of fire occurring is about as great as could be found, while the danger to life incase of fire, is, if anything, greater still. It would be a case of fifty children on a third floor with sheer walls all around and the only stairs leading down into the heart of the burning building.

There is another smaller matter, for which I also crave your indulgence. The kitchen range used in the boys' building is very old and thoroughly burned out. It is the one on which most of the cooking of the school is done. The buying of a new one has been considered periodically.

Sir,

I beg to forward you herewith a communication addressed to yourself, received by me under date of August 13th from the Rev. Principal of St. Mary's Mission Residential School, in which he requests Departmental assistance for the erection of fire escapes, the installation of a new pipe line, and the erection of a new laundry building.

This letter was held over while we investigated conditions thoroughly, and I enclose Blue Print and estimate received from the Westminster Iron Works Limited, calling for the sum of $1,062.00 in connection with the fire escapes.

I personally consider that the School should have some system of fire escapes, but in view of the fact that the buildings are old, and that some time in the near future it will become necessary to replace them, I do not feel that it would be good policy to spend so much money. I consider, however, that wooden outside structures might well be erected upon both the girls' and boys' buildings, and that the Principal's request would be reasonable to the extent of perhaps a total of $200.00.

With regards to the pipe line, this is largely a matter which should be covered by the probable date of the erection of a new School at Mission. If it is proposed to build one in the immediate future, the matter might as well be allowed to wait. On the other hand there is no doubt that the pipe line is in bad shape, and that no the water supply of any future school may be necessity be derived from the present source, pipe line would not be an absolute waste as the greater part of it would be utilized for the new buildings. I appreciate, of course, that the cost in this latter case would be met from the building appropriation instead of from current revenue, as would be necessary now.

The laundry building while old and settled out of shape, is in no immediate danger, and I would recommend that no change be made while the existing buildings remain in use.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The pipe line, which supplies water, light and power to this school, is badly in need of being renewed. Father Welch spoke with you on the matter, I understand, when he was in Ottawa in December last. He asked me to furnish you with some idea of the probable cost of the replacement. The following is what I have found out on the matter.

There is required, 6000 feet, of 8 inch, wooden pipe, for a head of 275 ft. The old pipe is 6 inch, but we lose much power in friction, and, in consequence, our lights are very poor. Iron pipe has a very uncertain life in this country, and wood pipe is preferable, especially the quality now made, and having the new couplings.

A new and straighter line needs to be surveyed for the pipe and the pipe and the connections installed. A new dam is required at the intake. Also, a new dynamo. The original dynamo is in very shaky condition, and the electrician of Mission City who repairs it for us says it cannot be further repaired and may go to pieces any moment. It is of seven horse power, but the new one should be of nine.

I have asked the manager of the Mission Public Service Co., which supplies water to Mission City, to have his men go over the situation, and give me his estimate of the probable cost. His answer is "About nine thousand dollars." This is meant to cover everything.

Trusting this is the information required, I remain,

Respectfully Yours,

Sir:- Re - St. Mary's Mission School Water & Light System.

In compliance with your instructions I made an inspection and survey of the water and light plant of St. Mary's Mission School at Mission City, B.C. The following is a report on the condition of the existing plant and suggested replacements and improvements.

ST. MARY'S MISSION SCHOOL-

This school is situated on the north bank of the Fraser river about one mile east of Mission City, B.C. It is a boarding school for Indian children, owned and operated by the Order of Mary Immaculate. About one hundred and sixty children are usually in attendance.

A farm is operated in connection with the school, the property comprising about 480 acres of which about 160 acres are under cultivation. The school buildings are of frame construction and were built quite a number of years ago.

PRESENT WATER SYSTEM-

The accompanying plan shows the layout of the present system. A small concrete dam about five feet in height forms a reservoir of about 10,000 gallons capacity in the creek bed. A six inch pipe line 4,300 feet long conveys...
water to the school. The pipe is tapped at various points to supply the different school buildings. The present pipe is in very bad condition and practically irreparable. To the fact that this pipe was poorly laid and in many places without cover may be attributed its comparatively short lifetime.

**LIGHTING PLANT**

An extension of the pipe line for 1,000 feet provides an additional head sufficient to develop power for lighting purposes. A 24" Pelton type wheel belt connected to a 7 K.W. generator forms the electric lighting plant.

The Pelton, although in a bad state of repair, furnishes sufficient power to operate the generator but this machine probably does not produce in excess of 4 K.W. due to a speed below its rating and to the fact that the commutator is practically worn out. No governor is used, the water being turned on at night and allowed to run until the pipe empties.

The transmission line also requires replacement. The wires being bare of insulation and always in danger of short circuit.

**OTHER SERVICES**

In addition to the services before mentioned several other operations are performed. A tap from the main line leads to the laundry where a Pelton operates the laundry machinery. Another tap leads to the barn and woodyard where a home-
made Pelton type wheel drives the threshing machine and wood saw.

Two inside hydrants and four outside are intended to provide fire protection. Two of the latter are in such close proximity to the school buildings as to be almost useless and in fact a menace to the supply in the event of a fire. Only two hundred feet of hose of small size, and now almost useless, is available.

It may be readily understood that with all the tasks required of the very small water supply there are many times when a shortage becomes acute. For none of the services is there ever quite enough power developed to adequately fill the necessities.

WATER SUPPLY-

The water supply for the school is derived from Darien or Mission Creek. It is carried by pipe line to the school site, a distance of approximately ¼ of a mile. This water supply also furnishes power for lighting and other power purposes. Darien creek rises north of the town of Mission in a country that is unsettled and which will probably remain so for many years, the country being fairly heavily timbered and with very poor soil.

The present supply has been in use about fifteen years. The school authorities are well satisfied with the quality of the water and I am informed that no sickness has ever been attributed to it.
A license No.3182 for 1 cu.ft. per second is held by the school and is of a priority as from 23rd July, 1873. No other record exists on this creek.

The flow of the creek varies from about 5 c.f.s. in winter to 0.75 c.f.s. in mid-summer. At the time of my visit, the first week in April, the flow over the dam spillway was 0.9 c.f.s., in addition to which there was a very great loss along the pipe line, possibly as much as 0.5 c.f.s.

**POWER AVAILABLE**

The minimum flow of Durien creek may be taken as 0.75 c.f.s.; this flow, however, does not determine the useful power. The power needs in midsummer when the flow is lowest are very small, while in winter they are about twice that required in summer. It may safely be estimated on the past fifteen years performance of the present plant that the useful flow is about one c.f.s. This should develop on a Pelton wheel with a useful head of 230 feet, about 15 H.P. considering a generating efficiency of 35%, about 9 K.W. would be available for use on the lighting circuit at 125 volts.

**POWER REQUIREMENTS**

There are about 225 lamps at present in use of an average of 40 watts each which, under the present system of operating the lighting plant, would require a plant of about 10 K.W. capacity for the reason that there is no means available of reducing the output of the generator. Normally the
requirements should not exceed 60% of the full load. It is safe to assume that the 9 K.W. available would be sufficient for all lighting requirements.

This amount of power would be ample to operate all other services combined, during the daytime. The laundry needs occur only once a week and at no time when light is required. The development of 9 K.W. would carry one half the lighting load and operate either the wood-cutting plant or the laundry at the same time, all that should be considered necessary.

The lighting needs of a future new school would be considerably less than present requirements as many of the buildings now in use would be dispensed with.

PROPOSED PLANT RENEWAL-

If properly managed, the present water supply is adequate to fill the needs of the school for domestic purposes, fire protection, and power, for many years.

The whole system requires replacement, the material being in a state of decay and the equipment practically worn out.

The plan suggested for replacement follows, with few exceptions, the general idea of the present system. An effort has been made to conserve as much as possible the small, though adequate water supply.

It is proposed to replace the present main from the intake to the school with a pipe of
a larger size making connection with the present service points as shown on the accompanying plan and profile. In the school area the pipe line is kept well back from the present buildings so that new buildings will not require a removal of location. The pipe line is to be buried with a minimum of 2.5 feet of cover.

Four hydrants are provided for fire protection service located at points to best serve the present school buildings as well as any future structures.

At the intake it is proposed to provide a reservoir of 30,000 gallons capacity. This is primarily for emergency use in case of fire when the electric lighting plant requires practically the whole flow of the stream.

**ELECTRIC POWER PLANT**

It is proposed to extend the pipe line as at present to a point near the existing power house to obtain all available head. This extension would require approximately 600 feet of pipe.

The power plant would consist of an 18 inch Pelton type water wheel connected by a silent chain drive to a 9 K.W. generator; the water wheel to be controlled by a mechanical governor.

**COST**

The total cost of the combined water system and power plant as suggested would be $10,340. In addition there would be the cost of installing motors for operating Laundry and for other uses.
OTHER SERVICES-

It is proposed to replace with electric motors the present water driven services in order to conserve the water supply.

For the laundry a 5 H.P. motor is necessary which would be hooked into the present transmission line by a short branch.

For threshing and wood cutting purposes a 5 H.P. motor is also necessary; this would also be connected to the present transmission line by a short extension.

The cost of these installations would be $700.00, including cost of power line extensions. This is somewhat less than replacing the present system with a similar one and providing new drains to carry away the tailings, which would amount to $556.00 in the case of the threshing and wood cutting installation, and $325.00 in the case of the laundry.

FIRE PROTECTION-

It is suggested that 700 feet of hose and a reel be provided for fire protection purposes to replace the present hose which is in poor shape. The cost of this would be $660.00

SUMMARY OF COST-

The total cost of the installation as proposed would be $11,700. A proportion of the cost of pipe line for water supply suggested is for the use of the power plant. A system for purely domestic use and fire protection could be installed for $7,000; so that the actual investment for power and lighting is $4,000.
The yearly cost of power and light, presuming a lifetime of 25 years for the plant would be $360.00 (interest and depreciation 9%). This is at a rate of approximately two cents per K.W. Hour as compared with seven cents per K.W. Hour quoted by the British Columbia Electric Company for the same service.

Attached hereto are summary of cost, bill of material, and plans of plant suggested as being the most suitable for the school.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

SIR:

I beg to forward you herewith an estimate received from the Rev. Principal of St. Mary's Mission Residential School, regarding necessary repairs to the buildings.

With regard to the first item, the roofs are leaking badly and in wet weather a number of pails are required to catch the water which comes through, I would certainly recommend that this be attended to as soon as possible.

(a) Building Repairs: Owing to the extreme age of the buildings, the steam heating, particularly in the girls' building proved inadequate to save the pipes from freezing, several were put out of commission, and while temporarily fixed it is absolutely necessary that the above be attended to as soon as possible.

(b) Carpentry: A good deal of work in this connection is necessary to stop drafts, otherwise making the buildings more frost proof, and I would recommend that this be done.

(c) Plastering, Kalsomining and Painting: This is necessary to repair damages caused by the weather last winter, where walls have been injured as well as damage by rain coming through the roofs.

(d) Stoves: The steam heating being inadequate to properly take care of the girls' building, about seven stoves are necessary to keep it in a habitable condition during the winter months. During the cold weather, it is now impossible to keep the children at their work on account of the low temperature in the buildings. I would recommend that an appropriation be made to this end.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
A great deal, of course, depends upon how soon the Department proposes to erect a new School. The buildings at St. Mary's Mission are exceedingly poor shape, but if they have to do duty for some time to come, the above repairs are absolutely necessary.

The total amount estimated as vitally necessary to meet present requirements will come to about $1,500.00.

Your obedient servant,

A.O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Quotations obtained should be submitted together with the accounts certified to by the officer in charge of work.

The usual procedure in constructive work of this nature has been for this office to obtain competitive prices for equipment, and orders have been placed by me; then when submitting final report on constructed works, all quotations obtained are submitted together with the accounts duly certified.

It is noted from your letter of 20th inst. that you request tenders to be submitted to you for transmission to the Department of Indian Affairs and it seems to me that this procedure is not what is contemplated by the Department of Indian Affairs but that they wish all tenders to be submitted when final accounting for the constructed works is made. Will you kindly take this point up with the officials of the Department of Indian Affairs and advise me.

In the event of it being necessary to submit all tenders to Ottawa for consideration, there will undoubtedly be considerable delay in the carrying out of the proposed works.

SIR:-

In reply to your letter dated the 22nd ultimo, File No. 153-1-5, I beg to forward you herewith a detailed estimate in connection with the repairs required at St. Mary's Indian Residential School, amounting to $838.50, with an additional sum of $328.00 for the necessary stoves etc., for heating, making a total of $1,166.50.

These repairs are absolutely necessary, and unless the Department intend to erect a new school in the near future, there is other work that should be carried out. The Laundry is beyond repair, as it is very old and has been repaired so often that nothing more can be done to it.

The Stoves, stove boards and galvanized protective stands to protect wood work, will be installed when the other repairs are being carried out, so I am sure that this will be satisfactory for fire prevention.

SIR:

With reference to your night letter of the 25th inst., received this morning authorizing only $150.00 for material for kalsomining, painting and repairs to St. Mary's Mission Residential School, and refusing to agree to the installation of stoves.

I beg to point out that it is absolutely imperative that the heating system of this Institution be completely overhauled before the winter. The furnace is worn out and is not capable of furnishing the necessary heating. This is not an exaggeration, as I have been at the School, and personally seen conditions for myself during severe weather.

The buildings are the oldest in British Columbia, and the wind blows right through them, so that even with a thoroughly up to date furnace or heating system, great hardship is inflicted on both staff and pupils during cold weather, with practically no heating system, as at present, the situation is desperate, and I must most emphatically draw your attention to the urgent need of its entire reconditioning before the coming winter.

As a matter of fact this should have been attended to long ago, but the matter was allowed to drift, as we were all under the impression that the erection of a new School would have been undertaken ere now. As there is an apparent chance of this for some years, in view of proposed new Schools in other places, it becomes absolutely necessary to put St. Mary's Mission School in such a condition of repair that it can carry on in the meantime. The cost of a new furnace would be approximately $2,000.00, and I recommend the purchase of stoves at a cost of $328.00, as a cheap way of meeting the situation.

Your obedient servant,

LAUNDRY:

The laundry and all machinery connected therewith is in very poor condition. How the Sisters wash for a hundred pupils is a mystery to me. I do not believe that the building is safe, the foundations are rotted away, and this building should receive immediate attention.
Dear Mr Scott:

I have just returned from a visit to St. Mary's Mission, B.C., and as a result consider that a new school should be erected not later than next year; but should this be impossible, that extensive repairs be made to the present buildings, without delay.

It would appear that it is next to impossible to heat the building properly. In November and December they used sixty (60) tons of coal and seventy-five (75) cords of wood, and yet in spite of this, the children, the Sisters, and the staff generally, suffered considerable discomfort.

I may perhaps be permitted to draw your attention to some of the defects which were brought to my notice:

1. All the windows need to be refitted, and the outer walls, (particularly in the boys' school) shingled or covered with siding.
2. New foundations are needed.
3. Many of the pipes are worn out.
4. The furnace must be repaired.
5. The laundry is in bad shape, in fact almost falling over.
6. All the wiring is exposed and has been declared dangerous by the Insurance Inspector.
7. The couplings on the hydrants, (it was explained to me) are not the standard size, and consequently do not fit the hose pipes, and thus in case of a fire would be useless.
8. The Fire Department, (I was also informed) has
ordered nets for use at the school, in case of a fire, regarding it in its present condition as a fire trap.

More could be said, but it is unnecessary. You of course have long had the intention of building at Mission, and I feel that you will prefer to build a new school next year, rather than go to the heavy expense of repairing, this year, the present very old structure.

I have the honour to be,

Yours faithfully,

J. Welch, O.M.O.

SIR:

With reference to your letter No.153-1-5 of February 17th, addressed to the Very Rev. J. Welch, O.M.I., concerning repairs to St. Mary's Residential School, I beg to report that I proceeded there upon the 5th instant and went into matters with the Principal.

The old buildings and equipment are so very far gone that it is difficult to make recommendations for repairs, the general impression made, being that any work at all is simply waste of money.

However, as it will be at the best, three years before we can have any hope of a new building ready for occupation and in the meantime conditions being what they are, I would bring the following to your notice.

1- Boys' Building: The sills are absolutely rotten and the building should be temporarily shored up with rough timbers and skirting closed in to prevent (a) the winter gales blowing under the floors as they do at present, (b) the undue cooling of the pipes from the furnace.

The old Electric Wiring is in many places dangerous, and if a fire ever started in such a building the loss of life would be frightful. The Provincial Fire Marshall and local Fire Chief have registered severe complaints of the Fire hazard in this School. This wiring should be looked to.

Roof: The roof needs refacing, water pours down in many places. That part over the kitchen needs reshingling. In addition the whole of the South Wall, that is the most exposed to winter winds, should be papered and covered with siding. There is no paper in the old wall and wind and snow blow through freely in the winter.

FURNACE: There are seventy tubes gone in the boiler, the fire bricks are all burnt out and nearly all the piping distributing the heat from the central heating plant to the buildings is defective. Steam escaped in clouds from under the houses through leaks in the pipes.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General, Ottawa, Ont.
3-Laundry: This old building has settled to the ground round the sides leaving the centre of the floor at higher elevation. The roof has split as the rafters pulled away in the centre. During the winter snow conditions are very dangerous and the Medical Officer has condemned the conditions under which growing girls work there as causing anatomical injuries. A new laundry is imperative. Possibly an advance unit for the new School might contain this part of the equipment and thus meet the situation permanently?

I would recommend that competent Contractors be asked to examine the School in connection with the above Repairs and submit figures. The cost will be heavy, but conditions are so bad and so dangerous that I do not see how we can escape with less.

4-Fire Risks: Mr. A.A. MacDonald, Deputy Provincial Fire Marshal, called here while I was at Mission and severely criticised the conditions under which we keep these children. I was requested by telephone to see the Mission City Fire Chief who while the School is outside his strict limits has to attend fires within reach.

This gentleman, Mr. Routledge was most sympathetic while severe in his remarks on conditions. He states the construction of the building is such that in the very probable event of a fire at night chances of escape in either the boys' or girls' buildings would be very slight. He made the following recommendations as being absolutely essential:

1-6 Fire hydrants within reasonable distance of buildings.
2-1 Life net to take care of jumping inmates, cost according to pattern $125.00 to $235.00.
3-300 Feet of hose cost about $200.00.

The Brigade have had three fires this winter within a stones' throw of the school, that is about one mile from the Fire Hall and their time of arrival at these fires was 2½, 3 and 4 minutes respectively from time of alarm, so they give an efficient service. Chief Routledge promised every assistance in the exceedingly probable event of a Fire, but was most emphatic as to the terrible chances we are taking in maintaining such a Fire Trap as the old School.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt.
Indian Agent.
April 20, 1928.

Dear Father Welch:

I am enclosing, for your information, a copy of Mr. Indian Agent Daunt's recent report on conditions at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School. The situation is so grave, I am constrained to take a very serious view of the heavy responsibility, which both the Church and the Department assume by continuing operations there.

As you are well aware, for some time I had been hopeful that, by now, the outworn buildings would have been replaced; but necessary expenditures at other schools appeared to be more urgent. However, I expect the Kamloops building to be finished this year, and I can look forward with some confidence to the possibility of the provision of funds for the replacement of the St. Mary's School in 1929.

The present serious situation remains to be considered. To expend a large sum of money on temporary repairs is out of the question, and I am inclined to think that the best plan would be to close the school after this summer. Now that the winter is past, from the standpoint of the health of staff and children, there would be but small risk keeping the school open for a few months. The other danger - the loss of life by fire - will be comparatively less as the various heating units become idle. To further minimize this latter hazard, I have today written to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, authorizing the engagement of a competent night watchman, who will continuously patrol the boys' and girls' buildings during the night. I have instructed Mr. Daunt to cooperate with Father Maillard in the selection of a very reliable man for this duty.

I regret the circumstances which make it necessary to consider closing the school until the new building is ready for occupation; but this last report, indicating the grave danger during the winter months, has made it impossible for the Department to take any responsibility after next September.

One of the first questions to be considered as we plan for a new building is that of a suitable site. I believe that the present property should be used, as it has been the scene of much usefulness to our wards. You might let me know what offer the Oblate Order would be prepared to make in this connection.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Very Rev. John Welch, O.M.I.,
