April 20, 1928.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I was so impressed with the subject matter of your 1-8-A of the 7th ultimo, concerning conditions at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, that I am seriously considering closing it before next winter. Enclosed you will find a copy of my letter of today's date to the Very Reverend Father J. Welch.

I wish to safeguard the lives of the staff and children living in the school, by the appointment of a competent night watchman, who will continuously patrol the boys' and girls' buildings during the night. You, in conjunction with the Reverend Principal, should select a man, who will be paid by school funds. At a later date, I will arrange a grant to the Principal to cover the cost of this special service. I will rely on you and on Father Haillard to see that a most reliable man is secured.

You will please instruct the Reverend Principal and personally see that the children are thoroughly familiar with the fire escapes and other exits. You should also see that the fire extinguishers and hose are kept in good condition and ready for instant use. If you and Chief Routledge of the local fire brigade are satisfied that a life net should be secured, you may purchase one at an approximate cost of $175.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr Scott:

In reply to your recent communication No I53-I-5, informing me that the Department may find necessary to close St Mary's Residential School next summer until a new building is erected, I must frankly admit that such a possibility fills me with alarm.

On Thursday last Mr Daunt, Father Maillard and myself met at the Indian Agency to discuss the situation, and were united in expressing the hope that the Department would see its way to keep the school open. How this may be done with safety, and at a minimum of expense Mr Daunt's letter, which we have carefully considered, will explain.

As a suitable site for the new building, you consider that the present property should be used. In this connection I shall be pleased to place your recommendation before my council, and will write you later.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 153-1-5 of the 20th instant, with reference to conditions at St. Mary's Indian Residential School.

In this connection I met the Reverend Principal, who informs me that he has a most reliable man, named Mr. Vincent Frazzolare, who is in fact the only person, whom he would trust around the Convent at night. He proposes placing this man on duty each night from 9 P.M. until 6 A.M. at a monthly salary of $60.00 and board supplied by the School.

I have ordered a Net from Vancouver, which is quoted at $125.00.

I may say that the School Authorities are very much opposed to closing the Institution, and I can understand their feelings in the matter, in as much as once the children are scattered it will be difficult to collect many of them again. The other Schools being practically full it would not be possible to transfer pupils for the time being.

On the other hand, they request the Department to incur certain expenditures, in order to keep it running. Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

With reference to recent correspondence from the Rev. Father Welch and Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, regarding conditions at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, I wish to report that steps have already been taken to minimize the loss of life by fire. A responsible night watchman has been engaged for duty from 9 P.M. to 6 A.M., at a monthly salary of $60 - the school supplying his board. I do not believe it is necessary to secure a certificate covering the employment of this man, unless the Auditor General demands it. School janitors and caretakers in receipt of this salary have not been questioned. A landing net and other improvements have been added to the fire escape provision.

It appears that the school and church authorities are very much opposed to closing the school until a new building can be provided. They are quite satisfied to carry on if the Department will continue the services of the night watchman, as we have already promised, and if we will spend $700 or $800 fixing up the furnace and laundry boilers. I believe this should be done and I should be glad to have your approval for the expenditure. It will also be necessary to pay $16 per week for a few weeks until the laundry is in running order again.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 25, 1928.

Sir:

I am directed to refer to your l-S-A of the 28th ultimo, with reference to conditions at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School. The arrangements that have been made for a night watchman and for additional fire escape provision are approved. It is true that the Church authorities are opposed to closing the school and are willing to carry on if the Department assist at the present time. The Deputy Superintendent general has authorized an expenditure of approximately $450 for the relining of the boiler in the furnace room and the replacement of seventy tubes. When the laundry is in working order again, you may submit a voucher in favour of the Rev. Principal reimbursing him for the special expenditure of $16 per week occasioned by the necessity of sending out the laundry. It is understood that the laundry will be put in condition as soon as possible.

PART I

THE CONTRACT -

The bidder to whom an award is made shall execute a written contract with the Department of Indian Affairs, and, if bond is required, furnish good and approved bond within seven days after receiving the form of contract and bond for execution.

If the bidder to whom the award is made fails to enter into a contract as herein provided, the award will be cancelled, and an award may be made to the bidder whose proposal is the most acceptable in the opinion of the Department of Indian Affairs.

THE ENGINEER

The word "Engineer" used in these specifications or in the contract means the District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, Vancouver, B.C. acting on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs, who will be represented by an assistant or inspector authorised to act for him.

On all questions concerning the execution of the work and the determination of costs, the decision of the engineer shall be final.
THE CONTRACTOR

The word "Contractor" used in these specifications or in the contract means the person, firm or corporation with whom the contract is made by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The contractor shall, during the progress of the work, be represented on the works in person or by a foreman or duly designated agent, and instructions or information given by the engineer to the contractor, foreman or agent shall be considered as having been given to the contractor.

MATERIAL AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials, other than tools, sand and aggregate required will be delivered f.o.b. car Mission by the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service. Reasonable notice as to materials required but not covered by these specifications must be given to the engineer by the contractor.

The contractor will supply all tools required for the excavation, backfilling, grubbing, clearing and construction of concrete work.

All tools required for the fitting of pipes and parts thereof will be supplied by the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service.

All work shall be done and completed in a thorough and workmanlike manner notwithstanding any omission from these specifications or drawings.

All work done must be satisfactory to the engineer; work not in accordance with these specifications in the opinion of the engineer, shall be made to conform thereto.

DELAYS

The contractor shall receive no compensation for delays or hindrances to the work, except when, in the judgment of the engineer, direct or unavoidable extra cost to the contractor is caused by the failure of the Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service to provide necessary information or materials for the installation.

All decisions of the engineer with regard to any claims for compensation shall be accepted by the contractor and regarded by him as final.

CHANGES

The engineer may, upon notice to the contractor, make such changes in the designs and materials supplied as the engineer may deem advisable; if such changes result in an increase or decrease of cost to the contractor the engineer will make such additions or reductions on account thereof as he may deem reasonable and proper, and his action shall be final.
EXTRA WORK

In connection with the work covered by this contract the engineer may order work not covered by these specifications. Such work will be classed as extra work and will be ordered in writing. No extra work will be paid for unless ordered in writing and only at the rate or amount fixed upon in the written order.

INSPECTION

All work done in this contract will be subject to inspection.

All work that does not conform to the specifications accepted through oversight or otherwise may be rejected at any stage of the work.

ERRORS AND OMISSIONS

The contractor will not be allowed to take advantage of any error or omission in these specifications; suitable instructions will be given where an error or omission is discovered.

SPECIFICATIONS AND DRAWINGS

The engineer will furnish the contractor with such detail plans and information as he may consider necessary for the contractor's guidance.

DAMAGES

The contractor will be held responsible and required to make good, at his own expense, all damages to person or property caused by carelessness or neglect on the part of the contractor, his agent or employees.

CHARACTER OF WORKMEN

The contractor shall not allow his agents or employees to trespass on lands or premises in the vicinity of the work; and shall, when required by the engineer, discharge any person in his employ who is, in the opinion of the engineer, disorderly, dangerous, incompetent or objectionable.

METHOD AND APPLIANCES

The method and appliances adopted by the contractor shall be such as will, in the opinion of the engineer, secure satisfactory quality of work and enable the contractor to complete the work in the time agreed upon.

PROTECTION

The contractor shall be responsible for all material furnished him and for the care of all work until its completion and final acceptance.
The contractor will be responsible for the safety of all men engaged upon the work and shall adopt such methods of construction as will ensure their well-being, and shall accept full liability for all damage suits, claims for compensation, etc., arising out of any injury to an employee working under his control.

COMPLETION OF WORK

The contractor shall complete the work in the time agreed in this contract and shall, upon its completion remove all plant, rubbish or unused material at his own expense.

INTERFERENCE WITH PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

The water supply as at present must be maintained throughout the work by the contractor.

ROAD CROSSINGS

All road crossings must be maintained by the contractor in a manner approved by the Department of Highways.

PART II

Work to be performed by contractor.

CLEANING CREEK

All lands flooded by the construction of the dam shown on the attached plans will be cleared of debris and vegetable matter, as will also be the banks of the flooded lands to an elevation two feet above the spillway crest. Lands along the creek above the dam which may be flooded with a water elevation two feet above the spillway crest will also be cleaned.

DAM AND INTAKE WORK

A concrete dam and intake built in accordance with the attached plans will be constructed at the point shown on the plans, the concrete used to be properly mixed and of proper proportions to pass a compression test of 2500 lbs. per sq. inch after 28 days under standard testing methods.

CLEARING

Sufficient land is to be cleared so that the pipe line may be properly laid in accordance with the attached plans.
EXCAVATION FOR PIPE AND BACKFILLING

Sufficient excavating will be done so that all pipes may be properly laid to a depth of at least two and one-half feet below ground surface. All earth excavated will be backfilled.

LAYING PIPE, INSTALLING VALVES, HYDRANTS AND OTHER WORK

The pipe and pertinent parts shown in the attached plans to be laid in a proper manner. All pipe to be subjected to a test for leaks before ditch in which it is laid is backfilled. Connections to all service pipes to be made as shown on plan.

TIME ALLOWANCE AND PAYMENT FOR WORK

Work shall be commenced by the contractor within ten (10) days and shall be completed thirty (30) days after the execution of the contract on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs.

The contractor shall, at all times during the continuation of the contract, prosecute the work with such force and equipment as in the judgment of the engineer are sufficient to complete it within the specified time.

Upon completion of the work, due notice shall be given by the contractor to the engineer inspecting the work, and, if same is found to be satisfactory, payment will be made from the office of the District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service at Vancouver, acting on behalf of the Department of Indian Affairs, within a reasonable time from date of its inspection.

SUMMARY

The contractor hereby agrees to carry out the work necessary in accordance with the said plans and specifications for a total of $2000.00
The contractor furthermore guarantees that the above work, when completed by him, shall conform as nearly as possible, in all respects, to the requirement and details laid down in these plans and specifications.

Dear Commissioner Ditchburn:

I have been considering very seriously the condition of the St. Mary's Mission School, and I am convinced that we should not take the responsibility of conducting this school with its full quota of pupils, even with the additional protection of a night watchman.

My suggestion is that we should vacate the top dormitories, turn the class rooms into dormitories and erect temporary classrooms outside the building. This may entail some difficulties in administration, but in comparison with the risk of loss of life by fire, the difficulties are negligible. The outside classrooms would not be costly, and the pupils would probably be benefitted by the change.

Will you kindly take this matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt and Father Welch and carry out the proposed changes?

You might advise me at Ottawa as to whether my suggestion is adopted, and if it is not, I think the school will have to be closed.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

Dear Commissioner Ditchburn:

I have been considering very seriously the condition of the St. Mary's Mission School, and I am convinced that we should not take the responsibility of conducting this school with its full quota of pupils, even with the additional protection of a night watchman.

My suggestion is that we should vacate the top dormitories, turn the classrooms into dormitories and erect temporary classrooms outside the building. This may entail some difficulties in administration, but in comparison with the risk of loss of life by fire, the difficulties are negligible. The outside classrooms would not be costly, and the pupils would probably be benefitted by the change.

Will you kindly take this matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt and Father Welch and carry out the proposed changes?

You might advise me at Ottawa as to whether my suggestion is adopted, and if it is not, I think the school will have to be closed.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) Duncan C. Scott.
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th with regard to St. Mary's Mission School, written from Kamloops. This reached my office on the 20th on which date I was in Vancouver. I had been to New Westminster on the 21st and returned to Victoria on the 22nd and immediately wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt on the matter of your suggested change.

Yesterday I received a reply from the Agent in which he informs me that he has had a conference with Reverend Father Welch and Reverend Father Maillard, Principal of the School, and while in general your views are approved of, it is thought that better results would be obtained if outside dormitories were erected instead of outside class-rooms. The Agent's remarks in this connection are as hereunder quoted, and I am inclined to agree with him.

"To meet this difficulty, therefore, I would suggest that instead of building temporary outside class-rooms, temporary outside dormitories be erected upon the plan of an Army Hut and capable of accommodating sixty beds each, arranged thirty on each side with a narrow passage down the middle and a door on either end. These could be adequately heated by two stoves each, and would eliminate all danger from fire, the extra cost of their construction over the class-rooms would be very slight, and the buildings themselves could be utilized later for such purposes as manual training etc. in connection with the new School when built."

In your letter of the 17th you did not intimate as to whether the cost of the new buildings would be borne by the Department or by the Church authorities, but as Agent Daunt states that these buildings could be used later on in connection with the new school, when built, I take it that it is expected they will be erected at the cost of the Department.

The buildings such as suggested by Mr. Indian Agent Daunt would necessarily have to be approximately 180 feet long by about 20 feet wide, but I think it would be much more preferable to make them wider and shorter in order that there may be four rows of fifteen beds as per attached schedule. These buildings would be of frame construction, rustic outside with "V" joint sheeting inside, 10 ft. walls and ceiled and would give ample cubicle space for sixty persons. Mr. Brown,

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

I have your 15/12379 of the 28th ultimo, concerning the situation at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School. I note that the cost of erecting temporary outside dormitories would be approximately $12,000. I regret that I cannot authorize such an expenditure, as the scheme is only a temporary one. It is quite probable that the new main building will be erected on another site.

I should be grateful if you would carry out the proposal in my letter from Kamloops. You should arrange for the erection of an inexpensive building, divided into two suitable classrooms. The materials, at a later date, might be used for outbuildings at the new school. The heating should be by box stove, and, when making the arrangements, you should keep in mind that it is but a temporary plan and that no unnecessary expense should be incurred. The only foundation required would be wooden sills, and the building need not be painted. I would suggest that the cost be not more than $3,000.

I am satisfied that this arrangement, which you are authorized to make, is the most economical and will result in the least difficulties in the matter of administration. If the classrooms in the old building are turned into dormitories, the supervision will be easier than if two outside buildings were in use.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re St. Mary's Indian Residential School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with further reference to the proposed alterations at St. Mary's School, at Mission.

In reply I beg to say that this letter reached my office during my long absence in the North, and this, with alterations going on in the office, has thrown me back considerably in my work. I may say, however, that your suggestion that the children should be removed from the top dormitories and the class rooms used for dormitory purposes, and outside class rooms being erected to substitute those at present in use, is impossible of accomplishment in view of the fact that the class rooms are not large enough to accommodate any more than but a small percentage of the pupils.

On the 9th instant, I made a personal investigation of the building and found that except for one dormitory, the fire hazards in the main buildings are no worse than they have been ever since 1911. As a matter of fact they are somewhat better, as wooden fire escapes have been erected as the result of my inspection and report during that year.

These two schools (boys and girls) as you no doubt are aware, are at least 150 yards apart with a chapel building between. These buildings are heated by a hot water system, the furnace being located in the basement of the chapel. Therefore, the fire hazard is extremely low. The buildings are old, a fact of which we are well aware, but that does not make them hazardous.

In the boys' building, there is one main, large dormitory approximately 33'x60', in which there are forty-six beds. Immediately over the kitchen there is an attic, which has been fitted up for a dormitory, and this is 20'x36' and contains thirteen beds, and to my mind, whatever fire hazard there is about this pile of buildings, it is in connection with this small dormitory over the kitchen, for if a fire were to take place in the kitchen, the pupils in the small dormitory would be in a perilous position.

I have had the needs of this school in mind for some time and I believe that the only solution is to erect a complete new main building. The Department is now in communication with the church authorities, regarding the transfer of the site.

A few thousand dollars in the Supplementary Estimates could not be used to advantage. What is needed is $150,000, or more, for a new main building. I am hoping to include this in next year's Main Estimates.

To prevent any loss of life in the event of fire at the old boarding school, the Department is paying for the services of a night watchman, who makes a continuous patrol of the property. This is, of course, an interim arrangement, until funds for a new building can be appropriated.

Yours faithfully,

SIR:-

In reply to your letter No. 153-1-5 of the 1st, instant, regarding conditions at St. Mary's Mission School, I beg to inform you that in my opinion, the building is not only a fire hazard, but because of its age, is not properly speaking, weatherproof for young children.

The wind blows in one wall and out the other, and wreaths of snow may be seen along the walls, and for that matter may be felt round ones neck in bed.

This has been an exceptionally mild winter so no harm has been done, but even so, the cold in the school was most marked, and I always felt much warmer out on the road after leaving it.

I do not understand your allusion to the constant fire patrol, for which the Department is paying? According to our Records, the last account for this service was passed on January 31st, 1929, under Voucher No. 549, for $122.00 in favour of Rev. E. Maillard, then Principal. The service was a temporary one, pending the erection of outside fire escapes.

Everything about the building is so old, that apart from cold and draughts, it is never safe from fire, and such is the opinion of the local fire brigade. There is no doubt that this School should be one of the first to be renewed when the Department is able to undertake such work.

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. Inspector G. H. Barry, dated March 16 & 17, 1931, on his Inspection of the ST. MARY'S MISSION INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 153-1-6.

FIRE PROTECTION:

I wish to recommend the installation of an electric fire alarm in each building.

DORMITORIES:

The dormitories are very clean. They are not overcrowded. The space occupied in the past by retired missionaries, now living in New Westminster, has been turned into extra dormitory accommodation. Ventilation is satisfactory.

The Principal wishes for 20 new beds. These are to replace beds completely worn out. I consider that these are needed as soon as possible.

WATER SUPPLY:

The water for the school is piped from a creek. The quantity appears to be unlimited and the quality is excellent. There is a dam in the creek and a small reservoir. This dam and reservoir were built in 1928. The water in the reservoir is about 15 ft. below the spill-way. This is due to a bad leak in the retaining wall on the west side. There is the beginning of a cave in here. The tank or reservoir will not fill up owing to the leak, which is situated as far as I could discover between 10 and 25 feet from the S.W. corner of the reservoir.

I respectfully suggest that steps be taken as soon as possible to repair the reservoir.

LIGHT:

The dynamo was installed in 1928. It is reported by Mr. Warren to have been so installed that it is running backwards. I do not know if this makes much difference to the current produced.

Covered Manure Pit: This is a building 60 ft. by 30 ft. It is set on a cement foundation and covered with a galvanized roof. It was built last November. The forms for the cement for the back wall were not put down to the bottom of the cement wall, nor was there any excavation of the bank behind the shed made at the time it was built.

The weight of the clay bank has bent the cement wall into a bow, thus throwing out the superstructure. To save the shed, the clay has now been excavated at the back and iron ties put in to hold the cement wall from giving any further. The cement wall has of course become cracked. An 80 ft. piece of rain trough is required for the front of the roof to prevent the rain from being blown into the shed. I do not know who was responsible for the building of this shed, but I consider the work to have been very badly done.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: St. Mary's School, Mission, Water Supply.

An inspection was made of the reservoir of the above mentioned water system on the 24th of May. I found that repairs had been effected to the leak in the reservoir by the school authorities but that a leak was occurring through the creek bank above the reservoir which would not allow it to fill completely.

As I was unable to see the Principal of the school at the time of my visit, I interviewed Mr. Purcell who has charge of the system and under whose supervision repairs to the reservoir were carried out. He stated that the probable cause of the leak was the presence of poor ground at a point about two feet up from the bed of the reservoir and in close proximity to a large tree. This poor material as well as the tree roots was removed and the locality refilled with good material and tamped. I informed Mr. Purcell of the other leak above the reservoir of which he stated he was aware and also that he expected to repair the leak shortly.

So long as there is sufficient water for the use of the school services no damage is likely to occur as a result of such leaks. The volume of water stored is not large and there is sufficient drainage to take care of such occurrences. The material on which the reservoir was excavated has held water successfully for over twenty years with very small loss, if any. It has been owing to the enlargement of the original pond and the breaking into new ground that resulted in uncovering the weak spots in the soil. Since these have been remedied as they have occurred, at very small cost, there is no reason to suppose that the reservoir will not hold water successfully.

W. C. Warren

EXTRACTS from Inspector Barry's Report on his Inspection of the ST. MARY'S MISSION INDIAN RES. SCHOOL on November 24 & 25, 1931.

Original on File 153-1-6.

Fire Protection:- I wish to recommend that six 10 in. Fire Gongs be placed in the school, and two 6 in. Gongs, one in each classroom. The work of installing these Gongs and the necessary batteries and wiring could be done by the boys under instruction. Fire drills are held regularly. At the one which took place during my inspection, the children were most orderly and showed that they had been well trained. With regard to the fire risk in these old buildings, there is nothing to add to my previous report. The Principal informs me that no heaters are kept alight at night and that a watchman is employed during the winter.

Dormitories:- The Principal has purchased four beds since my last report. In that report I stated that 20 new beds were badly needed. I have now to ask that 16 new beds be supplied. The dormitories are kept perfectly clean. There is no suspicion of overcrowding.

Sanitary Conditions:- In the boys' kitchen, another large sink is required. The boys of the Manual Training class would be able to erect this, should the Department provide the actual sink itself. This would cost about $10.00.

The outside Boys' Toilet is now too far gone to be worth any repair. I strongly recommend that the school be given $100.00 worth of the necessary lumber and the boys will be able, under their Manual Training Instructor, to erect a new set of outside toilets. This matter is now urgent. Nothing could possibly be done with the present Boys' Toilets which are a wreck.

The laundry building as reported early this year is a new building. It contains the usual tubs, two washing machines, and an extractor. About 1000 pieces of laundry go through the machines weekly. The boiler appears to be working in a more satisfactory manner lately. I have suggested to the Principal and would recommend to the Department that wooden guards be placed to protect children from the wheels and belts of the extractor and washing machines.

Woodshed:- The roof of the woodshed is in a perfectly hopeless condition. Rough lumber to the value of not more than $150.00 is required to rebuild this most necessary woodshed. The above sum would include the necessary shingles. Some rough poles would be also required. These the boys could cut in the woods. The boys of the Manual Training Class, working under their instructor, could easily construct the required woodshed. I would recommend that the rough lumber and shingles be provided by the Department.

Farming:- The roof of the old machinery shed is in a hopeless condition. It could be repaired or rather reshingled by the boys of the Manual Training Class, if the necessary shingles were provided by the Department. As lumber or shingles would be satisfactory on the roof of this shed, I consider that the total cost of the necessary shingles would not exceed $10.00 and the rough lumber for sheeting another $25.00. The total cost with nails would not exceed $50.00.

Stock:- I wish to recommend the provision of about fifty young apple trees of approved variety. A number of blanks should be filled in the "Hill Side" orchard, and additions should be made to the orchards. The young trees would not cost the Department a large sum and the benefit in the years to come to the children at the school would be great.

The whole brickwork of this boiler is in a very poor condition, and many cracks are showing. Attempts have been made to prevent them getting worse but with poor success.

This boiler was not properly installed at first, the supporting lugs being built into the brickwork instead of being supported on H. Beams and clear of the brickwork; also the smoke uptake is constructed of brickwork instead of steel which adds several tons weight to the brickwork of the boiler.

This boiler should be taken out and properly installed, which will cost approximately Two Thousand Dollars ($2,000.00).

I pointed out to the principal of the school and his engineer in charge temporary methods to strengthen the weak parts which if done will not cost very much and with care will last this coming firing season, but the danger pointed out is still there. After this firing season measures must be taken to have it properly installed. When this is done a new site should be chosen which should be on the hill side in front of the school where a boiler room could be cheaply constructed which would be both dry and well ventilated.

I gave this boiler a Hydrostatic Test of 45 lb. per square inch and found it in fair condition.

Internally the boiler is in a very fair condition. All the stays and rivets are sound, there is very little corrosion on the plates but the tubes are badly pitted, some of the pits are nearly through and no doubt some will leak before the season is over. They are too far gone for preventive measures and must take their course and last as long as they will.

I would recommend that 5 or 6 tube stoppers be procured at a cost of about $2.00 each and if a tube starts to leak the Engineer can plug it in a few minutes and repairs can then be made at the end of the season.

The fusible plug must be renewed at a cost of $1.50.

The firebars are in fair condition and will need no attention.

I have not issued a certificate for this boiler but will do so after the re-inspection which will be necessary when the temporary repairs are completed. At that time I will also set the safety valves.

Boiler No. 3000 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful inspection and hammer test and found it in very good condition. There is very little internal corrosion. The boiler mountings are in good condition and the safety valve works freely. The fusible plug must be renewed. This boiler is about one third too small for economical operation.

Dear Sir:

re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, St. Mary's Mission, Mission City, B.C.

On July 17th and 18th, 1933, I made an inspection of the mechanical plant of this School, which consists of,

One Horizontal return tubular boiler, 60" Diameter, and 14' long, having seventy 3" x 14' tubes using steam at 15 lb. per square inch, rated at 90 H.P., built in Ontario in 1913, but not registered in B.C., used to supply steam to the various wings of the School.

One Vertical tubular boiler 20" x 44" having fourteen 2" x 22" tubes built in B.C. in 1929, rated 4.3 H.P. and numbered 30000 B.C., supplying steam at 150 lb. per square inch, used for the laundry machinery, etc., also machines used for canning fruit, etc.

Ontario Boiler, no B.C. Number.

This boiler is in a very poor and even dangerous condition. There was no basement under the School and a boiler room was constructed at the rear of the building by making an excavation 25 ft. deep and installing the boiler in the bottom, leading the steam mains and returns to the various wings of the School through the ground without any protection against the conductivity of the soil, which in this case will take up approximately 40% of the boiler power, and their installation is very rigid. This boiler room is very poorly ventilated, dark and absolutely dangerous, as from its position it collects all the seepage from the high hill at the rear of the school, and it is badly drained. I was informed that when it was installed a wooden drain was put in but it has rotted away and caved in. I would like to point out that, as it is at present, should a leak of any magnitude take place the attendant might be very badly burnt before he could get out, as this boiler contains approximately 12 tons of boiling water and steam. Even if the attendant got out the steam and hot water would prevent anyone from getting down there and putting out the fire, so in that case the boiler would be badly damaged or even ruined.

Owing to the poor ventilation the boiler has been badly sweating which has caused considerable external corrosion on both tube plates and the plates exposed to the fire. To prevent this, at the close of the firing season the boiler should be thoroughly cleaned off, painted and left dry.

SIR:

In reply to your letter dated the 7th of November, File No.153-1-5, regarding the heating system at St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, I beg to inform you that the fusible plugs have been renewed and a supply of tube stoppers procured; the brick-work outside the Ontario boiler has been done over entirely and the outside repaired considerably. A new safety valve has been installed and a successful effort made to overcome the rigidity of the system by placing an expansion-joint in the main. The drainage system has been altered somewhat, and in the heavy rains of this Autumn much improvement was noticeable. An effort is being made to provide better ventilation for the boiler-room.

The School have gone to a very considerable expense this Fall to reduce the loss of heat in transit: the mains and returns have all been bared and covered anew, this time in heavy cedar boxing filled with first-class insulation and enclosed in double saturated craft tar paper.

The recent cold spell was a severe test of the worth of these improvements, and the system stood that test admirably.

A new central building of frame construction, with stucco exterior and plaster finish inside, and set on cement foundations, has been constructed. This central building contains the new DINING ROOMS, which will hold about 100 girls and the same number of boys; STAFF DINING ROOMS, DORMITORY for about 40 children, GENERAL KITCHEN, MANUAL TRAINING SHOP, DAIRY, and accommodation for the dairyman and manual training teacher, besides several other rooms, toilets, bathrooms, etc.

This building cost in the neighborhood of $16,000.00 and was paid for by the Oblate Order.

The old boys' building has been reconstructed and placed on cement foundations. The outside has been finished in stucco, and the inside after complete reconstruction, has been plastered. It is impossible to report in detail on the various new dormitories, etc., as the children had not moved in when I left the school. The central heating has been greatly improved. Most of the small heating stoves which were in this building have been removed, greatly reducing the fire risk. Steam heating is used. On the completion of the present reconstruction, I understand the Girls' building will be renovated in much the same way as the work has been done on the Boys' side. It should be added that the main roof on the Boys' Building has been covered with fire-proof shingles.

Sanitary Conditions:

The drainage from the buildings is to two old septic tanks. A new septic tank is being constructed for the new building. The drainage system appears to be working in a satisfactory manner. Though conditions were very adverse during my inspection, due to the fact that building construction was underway, and the usual smell of workmen, the various toilets were perfectly clean, and with the exception of the necessary litter always present while plasterers and carpenters are at work in a building, the school was throughout in a perfectly clean and sanitary condition. The children have supervised baths at least once a week.

Water Supply
EXTRACTS FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR BARRY (Concluded)

Water Supply:

I have nothing to add to my report of November 1931 with regard to the water supply, which appears to be satisfactory. The water is piped from a small reservoir and is sufficient in quantity and of good quality.

Boiler Room:

The building over the boilers is to be reconstructed this year (1934). The boilers will probably be quite satisfactory for another year. A special report has, I understand, been made to the Department with regard to the boilers here. I do not consider the boiler room to be dangerous for the attendants, though it is below the ground level. The steam pipes to the building have been uncovered by digging and later recased to prevent leakage of heat.

On July 10th, 1934, I gave this boiler a careful external and internal inspection and found quite an improvement in its condition.

Dear Sir:

After the visit of Mr. Arnall to our school I studied the rather long list of recommendations made by him regarding our boiler, studied it in order to find, if possible, some way to do all that he desired to see done.

The result of my efforts to figure out ways and means was not eminently successful. I cannot without incurring unwarrantable debts do all he requires, but I fully realize the need of it all.

This being the case I appeal to the Indian Department for assistance.

During the past fourteen months I have made additions and alterations to St. Mary's School which, done in the ordinary way of careful contracting, should have cost at least Twenty Five Thousand Dollars. The purpose of all this work and expense was to provide better accommodation for the Indian children of this district and to put our School into condition the better to serve the Department. In ordinary times we should have asked and received financial aid from the Department, but knowing the conditions of the times we did not urge that the Department assist in that way.

Now, however, that the Boiler-Inspector's recommendations come at a time when we find ourselves impoverished and indebted on account of improvements already made to the School, we must ask the consideration of the Department, and financial aid.

The Inspector requires the renewing of seventy-fourteen feet three-inch tubes, and that these tubes be annealed before they are installed, and rolled and beaded at each end; that a hydrostatic gauge, three test-cocks, and two water-gauges be provided, that the boiler be raised and placed on steel girders, and that new stairs be put in leading away from the boiler as exit through the side wall of the boiler-room. He also calls for a new raised roof and better lighting.

This extensive alteration and improvement program cannot be carried out for a Thousand Dollars, yet it would be worth much more than that amount to the School and, I think, to the Indian Department also. Will you please, therefore, request of the Department that help be given us to perform this work.

Yours very truly,

The Honourable the Superintendent General -

Attached is a memorandum from Mr. Sutherland with regard to the necessity for a new boiler in the St. Mary's residential school, New Westminster, B.C.

This is the type of difficulty that confronts us repeatedly in connection with buildings owned by the Churches where we pay per capita grants. It is still an open question as to the responsibility for additions and repairs that may be required from time to time.

With reference to your letter dated the 27th of October, File No.153-1-5, in which you request me to report, giving full particulars and cost of what is required to place the heating equipment at St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School in a satisfactory condition.

I beg to inform you that I visited this School, in company with Mr. T.J. Arnall of the Dominion Department of Public Works, who inspects the boilers in connection with our Schools throughout the Province.

We found on arrival that the Reverend Principal had already the work well in hand, as he could not keep the School without heat this time of year. Mr. Arnall was under the impression that, while the work was not totally in accordance with his report to the Department, it would be satisfactory and meet the situation generally.

I am enclosing a statement received from the Reverend Principal, showing in detail the material which has been purchased and the labour which has been paid for, amounting to $1,368.00, or about $700.00 less than was called for in the report submitted by the Boiler Inspector.

I would recommend that authority be given to forward vouchers for this expenditure, the more especially as the School has made wonderful improvements and incurred heavy expenditures in practically rebuilding the School, in order to take care of the educational requirements of the Indian children of the District, for which great credit is due them.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Mr. A. O'N. Daunt, Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C., has forwarded a request from
the Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, Mission City, B.C., (Electoral District of Fraser Valley), for the supplying of 100 single school desks, assorted sizes.

The Church authorities, under the management of the Principal, Reverend A.M.D. Gillen,
C.M.I., have carried out extensive building operations
and improvements at this school, without cost to the
department. This is the first request that has been
received for equipment, and I would recommend that the
quantity of desks asked for be supplied. The total
cost of the desks will amount to approximately $725.
Funds for the purpose can be provided from the item
in the Appropriation, "Miscellaneous Equipment -
Residential Schools". The best source of supply is
the Clarke & Stuart Company, Limited, Vancouver - the
largest dealers in school desks - but any make of
standard desk would be satisfactory.

I shall be pleased to have your approval
for incurring the expenditure, approximately $725, in
the purchase of the desks, and also request your
direction as to the firm that should be asked to quote.
The purchase, if approved, will be arranged through
the purchasing Branch of the department.

Deputy Superintendent General.

The inner surface of the Cataract tank is as smooth as tin-plished copper can be, and entirely free from internal mechanism. The action is purely a water action.

The bottom of the tank is tied and so prevents the clothes from being scuffled by the action of the tank. On the other hand the water above the clothes is made to move to and fro with great energy. **Curved Interior of Tank**

By means of the patented curved interior of the tank, the water is directed down upon the clothes in the very centre. The bottom of the tank, instead of falling away, as in other washers, rises in a patented pyramid form to hold the clothes against the sudsy water as it surges down upon them, and gives it a chance to do its work. Motor

It is mounted on a hinged base which swings on a heavy pin in the frame, and the weight of the motor is used to keep the belt tight. Solid Frame

The frame is made entirely of steel and grey iron, is well braced and very rigid and strong. Jacks are provided on all four legs to level the washer on an uneven floor and to prevent it from moving when in operation. In homes where stationary tubs are used, the Cataract may be left on the jacks in a permanent position.

The tank is carried on two heavy arms, which move back and forth in the frame to give the necessary action. The power is applied at both sides, and four coil springs are used to take all jerk and jar from this motion.

Mission City, B.C. August 22nd, 1936

Dear Mr. Doucet:

Last fall when I requested the Department's assistance in equipping our laundry there was no question of a Preventorium for this school. Since then the Preventorium has come into being and with it have come some new laundry problems which we believe best solved by a change in the articles asked for.

The changes are these: instead of the large angle we would get two ironers—one large "institutional" and the other as used in ordinary household; instead of the large barrel-type washer we would prefer now a smaller one, as per Beatty Bros., to do such small washings as may be required by the Preventorium. These changes leave a balance of funds which we would like to apply on a larger boiler. As is evident from the estimates supplied, the cost of a sufficiently large boiler will far over-run the amount provided, but we feel the need of all these things urgent enough that rather than forgo them we will make up the deficit.

Many thanks for your kind enquiry.

Yours very truly,

EXTRACT from Report of Mr. G. H. Barry, District Inspector of Indian Schools, Victoria, B. C., regarding his inspection of the ST. MARY'S MISSION INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on the 25th and 26th January, 1937.

Fire Protection:- In my last report I stated that four new fire escapes had been erected. For some reason the iron ladders at the bottom of these escapes stop short about eight feet from the ground. Wooden ladders, kept in a shed somewhere, are supposed to be placed at the bottom of escapes by the first pupil down. This is a very bad plan indeed and would of course hold up the escape of the pupils during an actual fire.

Owing to the terrible weather conditions I could not possibly hold a Fire Drill myself, and I would hesitate to hold a drill down the present iron fire escapes, particularly in very cold weather. In my opinion about seven feet of iron ladder should be at once added to each of the four fire escapes to take them to the ground or within a foot of it. This would make the holding of Fire Drills possible except in the worst weather and the children would have reasonable protection in case of fire. Should it be argued that boys would climb the escapes if such iron extensions be added, I may say that with wooden ladders available they can do this now.

In my last report, I mentioned that eight new Fire Extinguishers had been asked for, and though I looked for these, I was not able to trace them. Some of the present old extinguishers ought to be used in such places as the Manual Training Shop, but I feel certain that more extinguishers are needed here at Mission.

While there is good pressure in the pipes should it be necessary to fight a small fire, the Fire Hose is not sufficient. The Reverend Principal is measuring the extra quantity of hose necessary to give protection and will communicate with the Department through the Indian Agent.

I understand that the school authorities are prepared to build small hose sheds near the outside Fire Hydrants or Stand Pipes. I am informed that though dug out once a year these outside Fire Hydrants become frozen to the ground level and could not possibly be turned on in case of fire at times other than immediately after attention has been given to them as mentioned.

The Fire Alarm system is not a general one. The buildings are scattered. I do think that several new alarm bells are required which should include at least two large gongs on the Boys' and Girls' sides respectively. With such gongs in operation general Fire Drills could be practised.

In general I may say that while the construction of the new buildings and removal to the old have greatly reduced the fire risk at this school, I AM NOT SATISFIED WITH PRESENT CONDITIONS. I would therefore ask that the Department would have a general survey of this school made with regard to Fire Control with a view to the further reduction in risk to the children and staff, and that they ask for the views of the Indian Agent in this matter. I know that the present Principal is not satisfied and understand that he is writing to the Department at about the same time as this report goes forward to Ottawa.

SIR:

With reference to your letter dated the 6th of February, File No.153-1-5, regarding Fire Appliances at St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School.

I beg to report that I went over this School very carefully with the Reverend Principal. It so happened that Mr. C.F. Dawson, District Resident Architect, Dominion Department of Public Works, Victoria, was in Mission on business for his own Department and I availed myself of his expert advice, as the matter appeared to be rather a large one.

I am attaching hereto for your information, a Schedule showing the additions recommended by Mr. Dawson to bring the School in line with the requirements for buildings erected by the Dominion Department of Public Works. This School, however, is not Government owned, but is the property of the Oblate Order, and perhaps the question of whether we have a liability for structural additions to a non-Government building may arise.

I have obtained preliminary estimates for the improvements suggested and the total is rather alarming, but it seems to me that we could considerably reduce the figure while maintaining a reasonably secure fire service. The cost of the additions to the Fire Escapes, as outlined in the Schedule, is as follows:

Westminster Iron Works Limited -------------- $3,290.00
Vancouver Art Metal Works Limited ----------- 1,636.00

Both these figures are for the same Department of Public Works specifications, which are attached for your information.

The Hydrants, extinguishers, gongs, hose and reels, pipe etc., are quoted by Andrew Sheret Limited, of Vancouver, at $1,485.59, so the total cost would be somewhere about $3,121.00.

FIRE ESCAPES - There are, at present, two escapes at the rear of the Girls' building, the top of both opening out of the large dormitory on the third floor. I think there should be a counter-balanced addition to the foot of both of these to admit of the rapid clearance of children.

It was suggested that we should build a large V shaped one on the front of the building, which would

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.
would cost $411.00, but I think the existing ones sufficient provided the bottom additions were made, at a cost of $141.00 each or $282.00 in all. We should, therefore, save $411.00 on this item.

**BOYS' BUILDING** - There are also two escapes here, and two more are suggested from the third storey to the ground at a cost of $437.00 and one from rear gable extension to ground at $221.00, but here again I think that counter-balanced additions to the bottom of the two existing escapes at a cost of about $282.00 would suffice. This would save $656.00 on this building.

**PREVENTORIUM** - One Escape from second-floor to ground is suggested at a cost of $144.00, and I consider this to be imperative, as in the event of fire our patients in the Preventorium would be in grave danger without it.

The Fire Escape situation might, therefore, be met in a fairly adequate manner for an expenditure of a little over $700.00, though this would not, I understand, bring it in line with Government architectural standards, which would cost according to my lowest bid $1,636.00.

**EXTINGUISHERS** - A total of 33 at $14.00 each was suggested, but I think a lesser quantity would suffice. Provision was made for three on each floor of both the Girls' and Boys' buildings or 18 in all. This seems rather excessive and I think might be reduced with safety. Similarly you will note that in the Preventorium building six are recommended and I think this might be cut down. I would also eliminate two in the Bakery Building and two out of the four in the Barn.

**GONGS** - A total of six gongs at $16.93 each is mentioned, being three in the Boys' building and three in the Girls' building. It seems to me that two in each building should be ample.

**HYDRANTS** - Six are suggested. The six inch main runs along the rear of the buildings and it is proposed to place a hydrant at the rear of the Girls' building, Preventorium and Boys' building, and another in front of both Boys' and Girls' buildings. These latter would have to be connected up with the main at rear by four inch pipe. Another Hydrant is proposed for Barn, the cost of these is quoted at $62.57 each and the pipe (about 200 feet) at $152.40. I think we could eliminate the two front hydrants and connecting pipe, as the 750 feet of hose suggested should be ample from any one of the rear hydrants.

**HOSE** - Three reels each with 250 feet of 2½ inch hose are necessary. The reels are quoted at $63.80 each, the hose 3 x 250 feet at $55.13 comes to $165.39 and nozzles etc. about $19.47.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Although I have not had the pleasure of meeting you personally, yet I believe I am pretty well acquainted with you through several sources. I have heard our Oblate Fathers (Father Provincial, Father Forbes and others) speak often of you; Mr. Daunt, our Indian Agent, and Miss Dynes often mention your name, and last but not least I feel I know you in a way through your son Charles whom I had the happiness of teaching for a year at St. Patrick's College. So although we have not met, nor have had any correspondence so far on Indian Affairs, nevertheless I do not feel we are strangers.

I have a problem on my hands here at the School and I am asking your advice in an entirely personal way; this therefore is not an official letter.

Last October a Preventorium was opened on the School grounds for those children of the School Grant who are affected with T.B. It is a good venture and has met with a certain success this year. It is entirely in the hands of Dr. McQuarrie who has made very definite regulations as to how it is to be managed. The children are to be confined in the Preventorium, entirely separated from the rest of the School both for class and recreation. They are to be kept in bed a great part of the day, even the least affected. Now it is quite difficult to keep children (Indian children above all) confined all day to a room when they don't feel sick. Three of them ran away and upon being brought back they gave as reason that they did not like to stay in bed all the time. Furthermore several of them are in the advanced stages of T.B. and are a source of infection to the others. It is impossible to isolate them entirely; they are really Sanatorium cases. Dr. McQuarrie does not want any of the children sent home for the holidays, especially the advanced cases; he says they will lose what they gained. But the recent X-Rays of Dr. Lamb show practically no improvement in the advanced cases and they are a danger to the rest of the School. I understand a Preventorium as a place for children in the first stages of T.B. who can be cured but not for Sanatorium cases which require hospital care. And could not those children who are only slightly affected go to class and recreation with the rest of the School but have the extra rest and special food provided for them in the Preventorium? Would you not think that the management of the Preventorium belongs more to the Principal, guided of course by the medical advice of the doctor? If you could make some suggestions as to how the situation should be handled I would be very grateful.

Mr. Daunt sent the Government Fire Inspector Mr. Dawson to examine our buildings, which are poorly protected against fire, and upon his recommendation a contract for extra fire escapes and a requisition for new hydrants, more fire hose and extinguishers were submitted to the Department. The cost would be quite high, almost to three thousand dollars, but nothing superfluous was asked for. The Department replied that they had set aside
only five hundred dollars for St. Mary's School this year. I was very disappointed because the lack of fire protection is a constant worry especially during the School term. I know the Department is short of funds but adequate fire protection is always a necessity in a School. I have also other urgent improvements (renewal of the lighting system, which is defective and dangerous, installation of hot water heaters and showers for the children and a dryer for the laundry) all of which would cost about two thousand dollars. Of course I know the Oblates are supposed to maintain their privately-owned Schools but it is quite hard to do so from the per capita Grant. I understand estimates for each School are submitted to Parliament annually. When should requests for special Grants be sent in to the Department in order to have the estimates for Parliament prepared well in advance?

Six weeks after I was appointed Principal Captain Barry made his inspection. He made an unfavorable report of the School finding fault with almost everything. But what was slightly annoying was his insinuation that the present state of affairs was due to the change of Principals. I could not see his reason for such a statement, his having come so shortly after the former Principal had left and no changes having as yet taken place. Would his report influence the Department greatly in its attitude towards the School?

The above problems have been uppermost in my mind for some time and I thought it best to present them to you confidentially in hopes of your being able to help me with some very valuable suggestions.

I hope you will excuse the freedom I have taken in writing you a personal letter not having as yet made your acquaintance, but, as I say, I feel I know you through Charles, who was my best student in class, and to whom I'll ask you to convey my fondest regards.

yours very sincerely,

Ottawa, August 6, 1937.

Dear Father O'Grady,-

I regret very much that I have apparently neglected to answer your letter of May 17th, last. I wish to assure you, however, at the outset, that I will be only too pleased to hear from you at any time in future and I will promise to reply more promptly.

I agree with you that the preventorium is an excellent idea and I can understand why you consider you should have slightly more to say in the management of it. Of course, the supervision of the preventorium and the regulations governing it come under the Medical Branch and it is not possible for me to make any changes in any of the instructions that they have given you. If you have not already done so, my suggestion would be for you to personally see Dr. McQuarrie and have a full and frank discussion of the whole matter with him. He has always impressed me as being very fair and I feel that such action on your part will result in complete understanding between both of you.

What Mr. Barry did or did not say regarding the St. Mary's Mission Residential School had nothing to do with the amount that we authorized for repairs and improvements. As a matter of fact, these repairs and improvements depend entirely upon the amount that we are able to secure when our appropriation is passed by Parliament. This year, we were only able to provide $500 for repairs at the St. Mary's Mission School. As a matter of fact, we have already authorized Mr. Daunt to install fire appliances, etc., at a cost of approximately $967.00.

Our Estimates for the coming session of Parliament will be prepared early in October and, consequently, any request you wish to make should reach us by that time. Such request should, of course, come through Mr. Daunt's office as it strengthens the matter considerably if you have the Agent's approval to what you ask.

As mentioned in the first part of this letter, I will be only too pleased to hear from you at any time. I trust that, as a result of a few months' experience at St. Mary's Mission School, you now feel that you have the work well under control. I am hoping that I will have an opportunity of getting to British Columbia next year.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

Re: St. Mary's Mission School,
Water System.

As requested I made an inspection of the above water system on December 6th, 1937, and again on February 10th and 15th.

I found, as had been reported by the school authorities, that the reservoir was leaking, apparently through the sides and bottom. Owing to winter conditions obtaining, with the ground saturated, it was difficult to determine just how much was seepage from the reservoir and how much surface drainage and ground seepage. I found that little can be done to overcome the loss until dryer conditions prevail about midsummer. The flow of the creek is at present quite ample to supply all requirements and make good the loss by seepage.

The cost of effecting repairs to the reservoir should not exceed $250.00.

POLLUTION OF WATER SUPPLY

In addition to the inspection of the reservoir I went over the watershed of the streams supplying the school and found a condition likely to have more serious consequences than the loss of water reported.

Several houses have recently been erected in close proximity to the reservoir, one house being located within ten feet of the creek about 100 yards upstream from the reservoir. The probability of the school's water supply being affected appeared so certain that I had samples of the creek water taken for exam-

It is evident that the water supply is being polluted, probably from the sources above referred to. The condition has been reported to the Indian Agent for action by the Medical Health Officer.

The situation is not satisfactory and steps should be taken to overcome the possibility of pollution of the creek, or a new source developed for the school's domestic supply.

SOURCE OF SUPPLY

The source from which the school obtains its water supply is a small unnamed creek near the northwest boundary of the school property. The creek in dry weather is fed by seepage from a high bank paralleling the course of the creek for a quarter mile or more. The dry weather flow is about 0.35 c.f.s., but in winter the flow is increased by surface drainage to several times that rate. The area from which
surface drainage affects the creek does not exceed 150 acres. All of the area is alienated and with the exception of several lots near the reservoir is unoccupied and little of it is developed.

The creek has been an unfailing source of supply for the school for a great many years.

Appended is a plan of the area referred to.

WATER SYSTEM

The water supply system comprises a storage reservoir of about 30,000 gallons capacity and a pipeline of sufficient size to provide for fire protection and power requirements. About 10 years ago the system was rebuilt, at which time the reservoir was enlarged to its present size. It is a wood-lined excavation at one side of the creek and is uncovered.

LOSS FROM RESERVOIR

About one year after the reservoir was reconstructed in 1927, leaks developed through the bottom and sides. Some repairs were carried out but were not entirely effective. As the loss was not sufficient to cause an interruption of the service a large expenditure was considered unwarranted. More recently the leakage has increased and on several occasions during the past two years there have been shortages. The diminished supply, although not affecting the school's domestic requirements, might present a serious difficulty in case of fire and, of course, the output of the power plant is reduced at times.

REPLACEMENT OF RESERVOIR

It is uncertain whether any measures taken for the reduction of seepage losses from the reservoir...
would be effective for any lengthy period. The timber lining is showing evidence of decay in places and the probability is that replacement will be required before many years. It would probably be desirable to consider immediate replacement of the reservoir by a tank, more particularly since the area in the vicinity of the reservoir is being developed and pollution of the water supply on that account is likely to occur from time to time, if not continuously.

At the same time the point of intake could be moved upstream from the present location and above the probable sources of pollution.

**PROTECTION OF WATER SUPPLY**

With the object of securing for the school a reasonably safe source of water supply, I would recommend that the following course of development be proceeded with.

(a) Secure as much of the area adjacent to the source of the creek as possible, namely - Lots 211, 210, 209; about 8 or 10 acres of the S.E. corner of the Cade Estate, and the parcel marked Lot 9 on the accompanying plan. Schedule of land ownership is attached hereto.

(b) Fence off the area surrounding the source of supply and construct an intercepting ditch to carry off surface drainage.

(c) Erect a covered tank on Lot 213 and move the point of diversion to a point in Lot 211, just east of the road allowance.

I would suggest that the land may be secured either by purchase or exchange for some of the unused school land in Lot 4 Group 3, and Lots 204, 205 and 213. It need not necessarily be carried out at once but as opportunity presents itself. At present the owner of
Lots 210 and 211 will exchange for the school lots 204 and 205, and will remove his house for a consideration of $200, and provide right-of-way for pipeline over the exchanged land. For the present this exchange would permit of the development recommended and probably remove the chief danger of pollution.

COST

The development suggested would require an outlay of approximately $4100, exclusive of land purchased or exchanged. The immediate requirements, changing the point of intake and erecting a new storage tank would require an outlay of about $3050.00.

ALTERNATIVES

Alternative to the changes recommended would be the development of wells, close to the school, as a source of domestic supply only - maintaining the existing system in its present condition for fire protection and power purposes. Such a source would probably provide a reasonably safe supply. The cost, however, for a pressure service is likely to be greater than that of the changes suggested.

Chlorination of the present supply as an alternative to the changes recommended should not be considered until all other reasonable measures have been taken to protect it.

RECOMMENDATION

I would recommend that the changes mentioned be carried out at the earliest moment possible and that the whole programme outlined be given consideration at an early date.

Yours truly,

W.C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Storage Dam, Mission Indian Residential School, New Westminster Agency.

At the request of Mr. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Mr. Webb recently had Mr. Warren make an investigation of conditions at the above storage dam which is part of the water supply system serving the Mission Indian Residential School at Mission, British Columbia. A copy of Mr. Warren's report dated March 10th, 1938, is attached.

Apparently the request for this inspection arose out of the fact that the storage reservoir was leaking. However, when investigating the condition of the storage dam Mr. Warren found that some people had taken up residence in close proximity to the creek above the storage works and there was thus so much possible chance for contamination of the water supply that Mr. Warren decided it was advisable to extend his investigations to include a complete survey of the water supply system at this school.

Samples of the water were obtained and upon analysis, show that there was contamination taking place. Immediately this information was available the local agent was advised so that he could have the school authorities take the necessary precautions to protect the school population. Mr. Warren's report, as to suggested action, may be divided into three parts:

(1) For temporary repairs of the storage reservoir it is estimated that $250.00 would be required. This expenditure would however in no way improve sanitary conditions nor could it be guaranteed that further leakage might not occur in the future.

(2) For an estimated expenditure of $2,050.00 a new storage tank could be erected and the point of intake for the water supply might be changed. This would be permanent construction work along the lines of a complete system recommended by Mr. Warren and would do away with the present open reservoir and at least considerably improve sanitary conditions by eliminating part of the possible sources of contamination.

(3) A complete development that would as far as reasonably possible, do away with chances of contamination of the water and provide a satisfactory service water supply system. It is estimated by Mr. Warren to cost $4,100.00 exclusive of land purchase or exchange. This third scheme would involve the securing of certain areas adjacent to the creek from which water is obtained and the removal of some houses.

Director, Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your 153-1-5, of the 12th instant, referring to the contamination of the water supply system at the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School. I beg to inform you that I have this day interviewed Mr. Webb and Mr. Warren, our Engineers, in this matter. The whole issue is somewhat complicated.

Firstly, there would appear to be no doubt that this water supply is contaminated, and further, with further settlement higher up the creek it is likely to be even further contaminated in the future. I first ascertained from Mr. Webb as to whether should we expend the $4,100.00 suggested to put in fresh works if that would actually solve the problem and prevent further contamination. Mr. Webb stated that it would probably do so temporarily but could give no guarantee that it would do so should further parties settle higher up the creek, as they are apparently proposing to do. The other alternative is the purchase outright or part exchange of land, but there would appear to be a hitch also in this procedure as it is difficult at the moment to say how much land would have to be purchased or exchanged in order to get complete immunity from contamination. The other alternative that suggested itself to me would be for the school to hook up with the Mission City water system, a matter of connecting up for 500 or 600 feet. I therefore telephoned Indian Agent Daunt this afternoon to ascertain the possibilities of connecting up with the Mission City water system, and as soon as he has any data upon this, he is to let me know.

In the meanwhile, owing to the possible danger of contamination at any time, I have issued orders to Indian Agent Daunt to order in writing that the School authorities see that all water now being used for drinking purposes is boiled. He is to send me

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

a copy .....
a copy of his letter to the Principal. He, however, informs me that both Dr. McQuarrie and himself have already instructed the Principal to that effect, though not in writing.

As soon, therefore, as I hear from Mr. Daunt as to the possibilities of linking up with the Mission City water system, I will let you know.

In the meanwhile I should like to know exactly what the feelings of the Department are towards expenditure of any kind in this case, having in view the fact that the school and grounds are not Government property, as most of our residential schools are. Is it considered that we should be responsible for works of this kind on what is, I presume, private property, or is it considered that the onus is upon the owners, and that when paid a per capita grant that protection of this sort should be given by them. I ask this because I am not quite clear as to what angle should be taken in viewing the matter in general.

Yours very truly,

G. S. Pragnell.

NEW WESTMINSTER AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT NO. 10

Sir:

I visited this agency on the 5th of May.

We discussed various matters pertaining to the agency, the principal one being the reputed contamination of the water supply at St Mary's Mission Residential School. This matter is being dealt with from the Commissioner's office. Personally I think, and Agent Daunt agrees with me in that the best solution is to connect the school with the Mission City water supply, at a cost, I understand, of about $900.00. It is now stated that there is no infection from the Japanese settler complained of, and that possibly the Provincial Health Authorities can prevent further settlement in the watershed. I doubt this myself, without purchase of the land in compensation. The attitude of the Department in the matter has still to be ascertained over the question of responsibility for expenses in the case, seeing that the property is not Government owned. Agent Daunt is to report to the Commissioner's office more fully on the matter.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant together with copy of letter received from Indian Agent Daunt regarding the water supply at the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School. The Department approves the proposal to purchase certain blocks of land in order to protect the school's water supply system. However, I regret that although funds are available for repairs and improvements at this school the Department cannot favourably consider purchase of these blocks of land. As you are aware the land at present used by the school is owned by the Church authorities. It is proposed to exchange part of this for part of the new land required. This would result in the Department owning some land in connection with the school and the Church authorities the balance. Present regulations require the securing of an Order in Council and searching of title by the Justice Department. I feel certain that the matter would become so involved that it would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to secure the necessary Order in Council. Under these circumstances I hope that the school management will find it possible to provide the $550.00 required for the purchase of these extra lots.

The Department would, however, be prepared to consider providing the funds necessary for the repairs to the dam provided these do not exceed Mr. Swan's estimate of $1,975.00.
