Dear Sir:

In a communication received from the Department dated 27th August last, File 153-1-5, it is stated that: "the land at present used by the school is owned by the Church authorities." This remark was made in connection with the water supply question for St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission, B.C.

I happened to mention this fact to Mr. Webb, of the Dominion Water and Power Branch and he stated to me that some years ago in the late Mr. Ditchburn's time when the Water Power Station was building the said water system for the School, the question of easement over the land arose, and Mr. Ditchburn in a letter dated August 1st, 1927 (a copy of which is on file here) stated that "so far as District Lot No. 2 is concerned, this Department pays the annual taxes on the same and holds a lien against the property covering the value of a new barn erected a few years ago at a cost of about $11,000.00. District Lot No. 2 comprises 155 acres and is deemed to be sufficient for all purposes in connection with the maintenance of the School. The Roman Catholic Church or Oblate Fathers own the balance of the property mentioned in my letter."

On December 1st, 1930, Mr. Ditchburn in writing to Indian Agent Daunt said "that in view of the fact that I ascertained whilst at Mission that Lot 5, Group 3, Tp. 17, on which St. Mary's Mission Residential School is located, is exempt from taxation by the Municipality of the District of Mission, no account for taxes should therefore be sent to Ottawa for payment. The whole of Lot 2 was exempted in 1925 from the payment of Municipal taxes but through some error on the part of the Church authorities, accounts have been sent in for the taxation of Lot 3, which, though adjacent to school property, has no connection with Lot No. 2, which is exempted."

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
In an Abstract of Title dated 16th of December, 1923, under heading of Charge Book 28/359/49566C, the following is entered:

"30th November, 1922, An Indenture made between The Order of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate in the Province of British Columbia and His Majesty the King as Represented by the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs whereby the lands herein specified are charged with the payment of $11,000.00 already advanced and any further sum that may be advanced from time to time.

Signed B. S. Stokes, Registrar,
Land Registry Office,
New Westminster, B.C."

These three mentions of this property which I discovered on file looks as though the Indian Department had an interest, anyhow in District Lot No. 2, unless, of course, the money owing has been subsequently paid off. As our files do not apparently show what has happened subsequently to this property and what interest we have, if any, in it, I thought I had better draw the attention of the Department to this matter. This was particularly so because of the remark in your letter mentioned originally that the Church owned the land, and it struck me that possibly these written transactions had been lost sight of. Of course, there may be somewhere in this Office correspondence clearing the whole matter up and showing clear title with no mortgage against it to the Oblate Fathers, but so far I have not been able to find anything further, and shall be much obliged if, for our information, you would clear this matter up.

Yours very truly,

G. Fragnell.
For D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Webb:

I have your 37332-2 of the 1st instant, which is in reference to improvements in the domestic water supply for the Indian Residential School at Mission, B.C.

You state that Mr. Mills has written you, enquiring as to the status of the project. In answer I have to say that the suggestion was originally made to the Department to purchase certain land to protect the source of the water supply from contamination. The Department, however, objected to the purchase of this land for the reason that the rest of the land for the Mission School is private property and does not belong to the Government. As an alternative, they stated that they would pay the $1,900 required for the construction of a dam; this $1,900 being according to the tenders submitted by contractors. The School authorities are to be responsible for this construction but, of course, to submit proper accounts as usual.

I am informed that this sum of money is not to be taken from any engineering appropriation in connection with irrigation or other works by B.C., but is to be taken direct from an appropriation set aside for School and Education purposes. I presume that after this work is completed the Department will require that the construction be passed upon as satisfactory before they pay the $1,900. I presume, of course, that your Department may be asked to examine this. Should, too, the sum of money be not sufficient the School authorities themselves will have to be responsible for any balance required. It, therefore, means that as far as we are concerned, we shall have nothing to do with the project, except as I suggested the possible request for examination.

Yours very truly,

G.S. Pragnell,
for D.M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School

The water supply for this school has caused us considerable concern during the past few months and at our request one of the engineers of the Surveys & Engineering Branch made an exhaustive survey. He estimated that the cost of placing the water supply in proper condition would involve an expenditure between $3,000.00 and $4,000.00. To carry out his suggestion would require the purchase of additional land. As the land at this school is not at present owned by the Department Indian Commissioner MacKay was written with a view to ascertaining if the school authorities would purchase the additional land required.

He has replied by stating that the school management has now purchased all the land necessary to ensure no interference with the water supply system of the school.

Considerable repairs and improvements are necessary to the school reservoir and wing tank and Commissioner MacKay has obtained quotations for this work from the following:

W. F. Swan, Hatzic, B.C. .................. $1,975.00
A. S. Rankin, Mission, B. C. ............... 2,175.00
L. Slack, Hatzic, B. C. ..................... 2,220.00
Commissioner MacKay recommends that favourable consideration be given to Mr. Swan's quotation.

Funds for the purpose are available in the current year's appropriation and as it is most important to have a plentiful supply of good water at this school I should appreciate it if the Honourable the Minister would approve authorizing Mr. Swan to proceed at once. I may add that when Mr. Swan completes his contract the Surveys & Engineering Branch will inspect the work.

Director.

MISSION CITY, B.C.
June 5th, 1939.

Dear Mr. Phalan:

Before Father O'Grady left this school for Kamloops, he mentioned you as one, who had always shown him the utmost consideration and kindness in all matters pertaining to the school. I would therefore ask you to please help me in a matter of great urgency which has recently cropped up. You are no doubt aware that Father O'Grady and before him, Father Gillen, made many and extensive improvements at St. Mary's School. However the lack of money prevented them from taking care of all the necessary repairs and I find myself left with a doubtful legacy, in the form of a very unsatisfactory hot-water system and heating equipment. This has long been a serious problem of the school and I would like to have it remedied as soon as possible.

Our heating plant is situated midway between the boys' and girls' buildings, a distance of about 200' from each. The pipe that carries the steam is uninsulated and I judge that at least one third of our heat is wasted; so much so that it is impossible to adequately heat the girls' building, which is larger than the boys'. To remedy this trouble it is necessary to have a concrete conduit built to protect the pipes and preserve the heat, carried to both buildings.

That is one problem; the other and by far, the more urgent is the installation of a hot-water system. At present, with a lot of trouble, we arrange for the children's baths in the laundry building. This is most unsatisfactory and is a constant source of worry in the winter, insomuch as this building is situated at considerable distance, and exposes the children to the danger of colds etc. What is needed is the installation of a hot-water system in the central heating plant, operating from the furnace. Then the children could have their baths in their respective buildings. I might add that a sort of temporary remedy was tried in the form of electric heaters, as it was necessary that we have some hot water in the buildings, especially for the infirmary. These were found to be of practical use because they were far too expensive and they are being removed at the end of the school term in June. That leaves us with no hot water in either building.
I have no money to install this necessary equipment and trust that the department, which has always shown such consideration to the school, especially where the welfare and comfort of the children were concerned, will help me. I have already forwarded estimates, covering the work, both the hot-water system and the conduit, through Mr. Daunt. This was several weeks ago and, no doubt, by now the matter has been referred to Ottawa. The work should be done this summer and I am anxious to get it started as quickly as possible. I have given you as many details of the affair as I could, in the hope that you would interest yourself in our need and try to obtain the special grant necessary. Unless we obtain this grant I do not know what we will do.

I received a Hansard report the other day and noticed where our school was mentioned. It was in connection with the number of children that are maintained here over and above the school grant. I mention this merely in the hope that you will take this added expense into consideration, as we are thereby left with no surplus to take care of the work alluded to.

Miss Dynes, at the New Westminster office has told me that you will be attending the Knights of Columbus convention in Seattle this summer. I hope that you will find time to visit the school as I would be very glad to meet you. It is too bad that at this time the children will not be in school, as we have a little band here that has consistently won first place in the Vancouver Music Festival, and I would have liked you to see and hear them. Trusting that you will give my request your favourable attention, I remain,

Very Sincerely Yours,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Father Fleury:

Ottawa, June 9, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Reverend A. H. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, Mission, B. C. Father Fleury in his communication states:-

"I have no money to install the necessary equipment at this school and trust that the Department, which has always shown such consideration to the school, especially where the welfare and comfort of the children are concerned, will help me. I have already forwarded estimates covering the cost of the work - both the hot water system and the conduit - Through Mr. Daunt. This was several weeks ago and no doubt by now the matter has been referred to Ottawa."

There is nothing on record here to indicate that the estimates to which Father Fleury refers have been forwarded to the Department. It is of the utmost importance that repairs to Indian residential schools should be undertaken, if at all possible, during the vacation period. I would appreciate it, therefore, if you could forward immediately the information supplied you by the Principal of the St. Mary's School, together with any recommendations you may care to forward. If this information has been forwarded to the Commissioner's office, please ask that it be sent forward to Ottawa.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

May 18th, 1939.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing quotations received from Fred Welsh & Son, Vancouver and W.F. Swan of Hatzic in connection with the installation of a hot-water system at the school.

The quotation from Fred Welsh & Son covers the installation of a storage tank, heaters etc., which are necessary to provide a sufficient supply of hot water for the bathing purposes of the children. As you are well aware, this has been, for a long time, an unsolved problem at the school, where we have found it necessary to arrange for the proper bathing of the children under very unsatisfactory and trying conditions. The installation of electric heaters proved a failure as well as an additional expense and what little help they furnished will soon be no more as they are being removed at the end of this month, leaving us in a very difficult position. You may see then how acute our problem is; the only satisfactory solution being the installation of heating equipment as outlined in the enclosed quotations. This installation will give the school a permanent and reliable hot-water system. The installation of the showers, included in the quotation, is of course a necessary complement of the heating system.

In regard to the quotation of W.F. Swan, you will recall how our boiler room is situated midway between the boys' and girls' buildings, with the steam pipes running underground to each. With the additional hot-water pipes it is quite necessary that some adequate insulation and protection be given these pipes, else a large part of the heat would be wasted, in fact, I doubt whether the hot-water arrangement would be feasible at all without the insulation as provided in the estimates. Needless to say, there are many other features connected with this whole matter, which will mean certain expense and trouble, for instance, the drainage of the boiler room. However the main items are the hot-water equipment and the concrete trench. I must admit that the installations are an expensive item and the question has me worried quite a bit. However I rely greatly upon your appreciation of our difficulty and I trust that the Department, in view of their past considerations towards the School will pass the estimates for
approval. I would greatly appreciate your making known to them our extreme necessity in this matter.

Very Sincerely Yours,

June 27th, 1939.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am sorry that I have kept you waiting for my decision in regard to the expenditure on the hot water system and concrete trench. I wanted to weigh the matter over very carefully before committing the school to the large amount of $1335.00, which is the difference between the appropriation of the Department and the total cost of the improvements needed at the school. I had hoped to find some part of the equipment, which I could curtail for the present and thereby reduce the expenditure of the school to a smaller figure. I found this impossible, inasmuch as the items, covered by the estimates, have already been reduced to the minimum and besides they depend on and complement each other in such a way as to cause dissatisfaction and unnecessary expense were any part to be put off till a later period. In view of these facts, I have decided to provide the balance of $1335.00 out of the school funds, as suggested in the letter of Mr. R.A. Hoey to the Commissioner, Major MacKay. I presume that the Department will advise as to the manner in which the school's share ($1335.00) should be directed towards the cost of the estimates, if they approve of my decision.

I wish to take this opportunity of expressing my appreciation of the Department's consideration in being prepared to allow the sum of $2525.00 towards the expenditure of equipment for the school. Naturally, I was disappointed in not receiving the full amount, but nevertheless, I feel that my request was given every consideration. Many thanks to yourself for your kind interest.

Very Sincerely Yours,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of June 16th, and previous correspondence, regarding the construction of a pipe tunnel and installation of a hot water system at St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School. You will recall that the Department advised that an amount of $2525.00 was available for this work on condition the school would provide the balance of $1335.00 required out of school funds. Rev. Father Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of St. Mary's School, has now advised through Mr. Indian Agent Daunt that the school is prepared to assume responsibility for the payment of this balance in order that these much needed improvements may be carried out. A copy of Rev. Father Fleury's letter to Mr. Daunt in the matter is attached, together with a copy of Mr. Daunt's letter to this office.

It will be observed that Mr. Daunt suggests that an account for the full amount of $2875.00, being the tender of F. Welsh and Son for the installation of the hot water system, be submitted to the Department, indicating thereon the amount to be absorbed by the school, i.e., $350.00, leaving a net bill $2525 payable by the Department to the contractors. Briefly, the Agent suggests that the $2525.00 to be provided by the Department be applied to the costs of the hot water installation and that the balance of these costs, together with the full cost of the pipe tunnel, be taken care of by the school. This seems to be a simple and suitable way of dividing the responsibility for the payment of the costs involved. Under these arrangements I should imagine that the Department would wish to let the contract for the heating system and allow the school to make their own arrangements with respect to the construction of pipe tunnel.

Estimate for installing hot water and shower installations to boys' and girls' schools, Mission, B.-C.

Dear Sir:

We will furnish all material for the installation of the following equipment:

Tank Heater.
1 - W-10 Dored High-Test Heater with a manufacturer's rating of 100-degree raise every three hours.

1 - Storage Tank, 42"x10', with a capacity of 600 Imperial gallons. This tank to be constructed with man-hole and to comply with B. C. Government Boiler Act, with Safety Valve as required under the Act. To be installed on Pipe Stand.

1 - Red-Head Steam Water Heater, #12, with capacity of 500 gallons per hour, with steam pressure of two lbs.

We will connect Storage Tank with Boiler and Auxiliary Steam Heater with 2½" flow and return pipes.

Connect steam and return from existing Steam Boiler to Auxiliary heater.

Cover Boiler, heater, and Tank with asbestos covering, canvassed and painted.

Connect 2-inch cold water supply to Tank with control valves.

Should present water supply now in boiler room be of insufficient capacity, same to be enlarged at owner's expense.
From Hot Water Storage Tank, carry 1½" galvanized hot water service to each building with ¾" return circulating system. On return circulation install a Hot Water Circulator, same to be controlled by electric Aquastat in Storage Tank. Connect same to suitable connection to be provided by owner, in Boiler Room.

Cover with 3-ply asbestos covering, supply and return Hot Water Mains to buildings.

Install control valves to each building from Storage Tank.

SHOWERS.

We will supply and install all necessary waste, vent and water supplies for five showers in boys' school and six in girls' school. Floor of shower room in girls' school to be covered with sheet lead and finished with cement, owner to install necessary partitions.

On water supply to these showers we will install mixing valves placed in convenient locations. These are necessary on installations of this description, to safeguard against any scalding from excessively hot water.

Waste from showers to terminate three feet clear of building, further drainage accommodation to be provided by owner.

We will further make hot water connections to the existing hot water supply in each building.

Sleeping accommodation and board to be provided for workmen while work is being carried on.

We will do all of the above work for the sum of $2,875.00.

Thanking you, we remain,

Yours truly,

FRED WELSH & SON.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith quadruplicate invoices from Fred Welsh & Son, covering the installation of the hot-water equipment, and also invoices, received from W.F. Swan covering the erection of the concrete tunnel. You will please note that these invoices are receipted, having been paid in full out of the school funds. The payment of these accounts is in accordance with instructions, received from the Department. I am now forwarding the receipts to the Department so that the school may be re-imbursed in the amount of $2525.00, which amount was allotted to the school for repairs and improvements during the current year.

It is hardly necessary to say that the payment of these accounts—an amount totalling $3860.00—has made very large inroads in our finances. Consequently I would be very pleased if you would arrange to have the account go forward to the Department as quickly as possible, so as to reduce to a minimum the possibility of an overdraft at the bank, which would make an additional drain on the school funds. This is a time of the year when much additional supplies, such as clothing and food must be purchased and I would like to meet the payment of these items without any embarrassment. I might add that Mr. F. Thelan personally examined the work that has been done, on his visit to the school and found it satisfactory. He assured me that the department would speedily re-imburse the school, when the accounts were received at Ottawa.

For my own part, I would like to add that the improvements made this year, through the kind co-operation of the Department, have far exceeded my expectations in the comfort and sanitation they provide for the children. In addition I have been assured by reliable heating experts that a considerable saving in fuel will be effected by the installations. I wish to take this opportunity of expressing my appreciation of the kind consideration of the department in making these improvements possible and also to thank you personally for your interest in the school and the welfare of the children.

Very Sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Father Fleury:

Following your visit to us yesterday we are very pleased to fulfill your request and submit for re-consideration the proposal we made in April 1938 to install our IRON FIREMAN Automatic Coal Burner in the main heating boiler of your School.

You advise us that the situation of the boiler room and other details are practically the same as in 1938, with the exception that the drain in the boiler room which we recommended at that time has been installed three feet below the boiler room floor, and this has been taken into consideration in presenting our proposal to you at this time.

The boiler room is located separately from the main building and is equipped with a Leonard HRT Steam Boiler #7769, with a rated capacity according to our records of 90 boiler horsepower, carrying steam pressure up to 15 lbs. As the distance from the crown sheet of the boiler to the floor is only 37" it will be essential for efficient operation of the boiler to provide more combustion space, and to do this it will be necessary to install the Stoker mechanism in a water-tight concrete pit 24" deep, and we have included the carrying out of this work in our proposal.

The Stoker then will be installed in front of the boiler and its operation will be controlled by means of a Room Thermostat, to be located in the Principal's office, which we understand is approximately 150 feet distant from the boiler room and necessary electric wiring has been figured in our price to take care of this. We understand that the main electric service is 220 volt, 60 cycle, 3 phase, and the service connection is located 250 ft. from the boiler room and it has been necessary for us to figure on carrying our electric wires this distance in order to complete a satisfactory installation.
As it may be desirable at times to operate the Stoker mechanism from the boiler room by your Engineer without controlling the same by the Thermostat, we will provide a Cut-off Switch in the boiler room to make it possible for the Stoker mechanism to be controlled when most convenient by the Engineer.

In order to give you maximum results from Stoker firing and based on the boiler capacity, we are recommending our No. 4-A Long Model IRON FIREMAN, which is illustrated and described in detail in the accompanying Specification Sheet.

You will appreciate the outstanding advantages of automatic firing by means of an Iron Fireman Stoker, first from the advantages you will receive in your School building from automatically controlled temperatures during all weather conditions. This results from having thermostatically controlled operation, and also by maintaining uniform steam pressure under the boiler by means of the Iron Fireman Steam Pressure Regulator.

Further, there will result a definite reduction in boiler room labor costs, as instead of continual firing by your Engineer (as at present), with the Iron Fireman installed it will only be necessary to clean the fire occasionally and replenish the hopper with coal, as the firing will be taken care of automatically by the Stoker as heat is required and called for by the automatic controls.

The economical operation of Iron Fireman has been provided in thousands of cases, by the utilizing of low priced and the smaller sizes of coal, as against lump coal or Mine Run Coal which is usually necessary when the boiler is manually fired. We therefore are pleased to submit our proposal to you again and trust that this time we may be able to arrange for the installation of the Iron Fireman Stoker, which would be carried out with promptness and efficiency and everything possible would be done to give you entire satisfaction.

Indian Agent,

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith the balance of the school estimates, covering repairs and equipment for the current year, as requested in your recent letter. The estimates cover the following items:

Primary class room. Due to the crowded condition of the present secondary grade class room, it has been found necessary to construct a new room for the primary grade. The labour will be supplied by the school, and the room when finished will be as up-to-date as possible, giving the little children healthier and more adaptable quarters.

Laundry drying room. It has long been a problem at the school to dry the washing especially during the winter months, when the season is very rainy. Up till now the room that has been used has imposed a heavy burden on the children and staff and is dangerous from the viewpoint of health. A survey of other institutions, made with the advice of a laundry engineer, has resulted in plans for a drying room, which will give excellent service and do away with the uncomfortable and unhealthy conditions hitherto prevalent. Quotations are enclosed covering the three different phases of construction: lumber quotation from the Valley Lumber Yards for the construction and insulation of a room 10x10x8; piping quotation from the Marshall-Wells Co. and the McLellan McFeely and Prior Co.; quotation on the rack carriers from the Beatty Brothers Ltd. As in the case of the class room the labour and installation will be done by the school.

Fuellng system. Quotations are enclosed covering the installation of an automatic stoker in the boiler room. These quotations are from the Roswite Co. and the Canadian Summer Iron Works. Because the three main buildings are heated from the central boiler, it is essential that a system of controlled heating be installed. Besides the economy afforded by such a system, there is the much more important advantage of having a steady supply of warmth fed to these different buildings. In this respect the preventorium will derive distinct advantages as the present system does not supply the uniform heat so indispensable to the progress in health of the sick children. The amount necessary to install this equipment exceeds that allowed by the department for repairs and equip-
ment at the school for the present year, after the materials for
the class room and the drying room have been deducted. However,
if an amount, sufficient for an initial payment were supplied by
the department out of the balance of the school allotment, the
school could arrange to handle the remainder of the cost in a
series of monthly or quarterly payments.

In all of these items the main consideration has
been the health and educational advantages of the Indian chil-
dren. This is in line with the policy of the department in the
assistance it gives the schools for providing the utmost in the
fields of mental and physical education. The primary class room
will fill a long felt need in providing a system of thorough el-
ementary education for the small children and above all, will
overcome the crowded condition of the present room. The drying
room is designed not only for a more efficient handling of the
large weekly laundry, but especially to do away with the staff
and children working under extremely difficult conditions in an
overheated room. The proposed fueling system guarantees a con-
trolled supply of warmth to the different buildings, occupied
by the staff and children. Dr. McQuarrie has often mentioned
that the preventorium is not adequately heated for the sick chil-
dren, mainly because there is no uniformity in the supply of heat.
In this last item there is also the economic factor to be con-
sidered. For several years the school has maintained the extra
burden of caring for about thirty children over and above the
paid quota. This has been done in the interests of the Indian
people and in the desire to co-operate with the department of
Indian Affairs to the fullest extent in providing educational
facilities for the Indian children. To reduce the pupilage to
the minimum would, under present circumstances, bring a strong
protest from the Indian parents. I can understand that at the
present time it is difficult for the department to raise the
quota for the school, but I feel confident that, where possible,
an effort should be made to assist the school to operate as
economically as possible. The recent reductions in the school
grants have been accepted sympathetically in the knowledge that
only an extreme crisis would prompt such a move. I feel very
grateful to the department for the allotment of $2000 for ex-
traordinary expenses at the school and would like to express
my intention to use this grant only for what is absolutely ne-
cessary. I wish to thank you personally for your kind interest
and co-operation in this matter.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Due to unavoidable circumstances, I was forced to make up my list of estimates in two sections this year. The first part, including the erection of septic tanks, toilets, root-cellar, painting, fire escapes and drainage tunnel (covering letter dated May 18th) were passed by the department and I am glad to say that the work on those items is almost completed.

In my letter dated July 9th, to Mr. Daunt, Indian Agent, I listed the second part of the estimates. This covered repairs to classrooms, laundry and fueling system. In an effort to keep the cost down to a minimum, I secured prices on material and labour, rather than contracting for the work. This took considerable time and accounts for my delay in getting the second part of the estimates through. The Commissioner's office advised me that these estimates were forwarded to Ottawa about July 11th. I would be very glad if you would check up on this matter, with a view to expediting the passage of these estimates through the various channels of the department. It is imperative that the different works be completed before the school opens in September. Needless to say, I feel very grateful to the Department for the assistance provided St. Mary's School this year. With kindest regards to yourself.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.
Ottawa,
July 29, 1940.

Dear Father Fleury:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant regarding the second part of your estimates. These have already been received from Indian Commissioner MacKay's office and arrangements are being made to purchase the supplies requested.

I regret, however, that we cannot see our way clear to allowing an amount of $500.00 toward the purchase of an automatic stoker. Apparently your idea is that the amount of $500.00 would be used as a first payment. Present regulations make it impossible for us to allow a grant in this manner.

If you found it possible to pay the full account for the stoker and forwarded us a receipted bill to that effect we might be able to arrange to allow you $500.00 toward its cost but I am not even certain that we could do this, although we have made such payments in the past. You will note the distinction -- in the one case the stoker has been paid for and we are just assisting in its cost; in the other case the auditor would question the payment as he would point out that we have no guarantee that the balance would be paid. I say this in no spirit of reflection on yourself but you will understand that auditors regard these matters in a very hard-boiled attitude.

Yours truly,

Rev. A. H. Fleury, O.M.I.,

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of August 2nd, regarding tenders on equipment required for the laundry drying room of the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School.

Quotations of both firms are for the same materials. Neither of them quoted on the "2 only, 20 pipe 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inch headers", as these are being secured by the Principal at the expense of the school from another firm.

Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd. included the cost of threading in the price of $114.40 for "800 ft. of 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inch black iron pipe", whereas though McLennan, McFeely and Prior Ltd. refer to cutting and threading in the item "800 ft. 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inch black plain end ammonia pipe—$111.52", this amount was not intended to cover these services, as same were provided for in the items "40 only cuts on 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inch pipe—$4.00" and "160 only threads on 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inch pipe—$32.00." Please see the attached letter from McLennan, McFeely and Prior Ltd. confirming this. The tender of Marshall-Wells B.C. Ltd. at $307.66 is the lower.

I trust the foregoing explains the matter and that the purchase of this equipment will be proceeded with at an early date as the Rev. Principal is anxious to have the improvements completed, if at all possible, before the school opens.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

Please accept our thanks for your remittance in the amount of $115.06 by your cheque #4083776.

According to payment voucher attached to cheque, this is in payment of our invoice #68661 of June 22nd - your order #26602A. Our records show this invoice as amounting to $118.38 with discount deductible of $2.32, leaving a balance payable of $116.06.

It appears that $1.00 has been deducted for some purpose, and we would appreciate it very much if you could let us have the details of this deduction in order that we might complete and reconcile our records.

Thanking you in anticipation of your kind attention, we are

Yours truly,

MARSHALL-WELLS B. C. LIMITED

WRB: NW Accountant.
Ottawa, September 10, 1940.

Dear Sirs:

Ch.No.83776, August 24/40 - $115.06

The above-named cheque was forwarded to you in payment of your account of June 22, 1940, rendered at $115.38.

In explanation I wish to say that Mr. A.O'N. Daunt, Indian Agent at New Westminster, B.C., when he forwarded the account under cover of his voucher No.291, July 20, 1940, $115.06, drew attention to the fact that Purchase Order No.26602A contained an error of $1.00, threading pipe - 4 only at .20¢ would amount to .80¢ while the account showed $1.80. Mr. Daunt made the necessary correction.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Daunt and if you require any further information kindly communicate with him.

Yours truly,

L.W. McCutcheon
Chief Treasury Officer.

Marshall-Wells B.C.Limited,
573 Carrall St.,
VANCOUVER, B.C.

Mr. A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith three bills from W.F. Swan, contractor, covering the following items of work, completed at the school this summer, and authorized by the department.

Repairs to root cellar $300.00
Two septic tanks $250.00
Drainage tunnel $300.00

In regards to the last item, you will note that the total cost amounted to $69.00 more than the department allowed. I have paid this amount ($69) out of school funds, receipt of which is noted on the invoice. This leaves a balance of $300.00, which is the amount authorized by the department. In each case the work has been completed very satisfactorily and I have endorsed the bills to that effect.

I need hardly say how pleased I am upon the satisfactory completion of the different work. I appreciate very much your kind co-operation and the kindness of the department in giving consideration to my requests. I trust that you will find the bills properly completed.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Chief Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I am writing you in regard to the estimates for proposed repairs at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School for this summer. It has been found necessary to change some of the items due to emergencies that have recently arisen. You can well understand these alterations in view of the fact that my previous list of proposed repairs was dated July 16th, 1940, and forwarded to Mr. Daunt under that date. At the time the repairs listed on the previous list seemed the most urgent, but a year has passed since then and we are confronted with new and more urgent problems.

The former list called for repairs to the boys' building, the gymnasium and installations in the cannery and certain washrooms. Now, I consider it more important to have repairs made to our water pipeline, corrections made in the wiring of the administration building and additional lengths of hose supplied. The installations in the cannery is still an important item as well as several paint jobs in certain rooms of the school. The total amount will run about the same as on the previous list. To explain the changes I might mention that last winter we had considerable trouble with leaks in part of the pipe-line, where the pressure is greatest. The fire we had last fall revealed that many sections of our fire hose is not in very good condition. I have already spent quite a sum standardizing our wiring and would like to finish it this summer. These three items with the installations in the cannery and the paint work should reach about the same total as the previous list amounted to. I want you to have this information about the change in our list so that you will understand why it is necessary. I am at present securing quotations on the above work, which I will forward to Mr. Daunt, within a few days.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

Following our conversation and your information re one of your pipe lines to be replaced we beg to tender a price of $598.00 for replacing approximately 750 feet of 4 inch pipe line on your property.

SPECIFICATIONS.

Old line to be dug out, pipe removed and replaced with a new 4 inch wood pipe laid in the same trench. Trench is then to be backfilled and the surface left as level as possible.

Connections to be made to present fittings, such as hydrants, stand-pipes etc.

All old cast-iron fittings, such as T's, bends etc. to be cleaned of rust and corrosion before replacing.

All new cast-iron fittings required shall be charged at cost.

No. 1, double-burlapped wood pipe of 300 foot head to be used.

All work will be done as soon as possible and in a workman-like manner, and with as little interruption as possible to present water service.

Above tender is based on a minimum length of 750 feet. If less than this a deduction of 75 cents per foot will be allowed, if more than 750 feet an addition of 75 cents per foot is to be made.

The above price is for double-burlapped pipe which we use as it protects the wood from fungus organisms and rot and is thus worth the extra cost. If plain pipe is wanted deduct 7 cents per foot from above price.

Yours truly,

MISSION PUBLIC SERVICE CO., LTD.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

When the Provincial of the Oblate Fathers was here a few weeks ago I discussed with him the possibility of having a Junior High School attached to the Catholic Indian Residential School at Mission which would comprise Grades VII, VIII, and IX, to which would be recommended Indian children from any of our Catholic schools for special teaching and study hours in those grades.

To make this possible it would be necessary to have

1. Two additional rooms, one for boys on the boys side and one for girls on the girls side.

2. Permission from the Government to allow eligible boys and girls to be transferred from other schools to this school.

3. Properly qualified first-class teachers, one for boys and one for girls.

We have felt for a long time that such a school might encourage the Indian children to advance a little higher in education and also fit the eligible ones among them to give leadership among their people when they grow older.

Knowing how interested you have always been in the welfare of the Indian people and your sympathetic understanding of our Indian problems here, I would be glad to have your advice on this important matter.

We hope to have a meeting of our missionaries and principals of our Indian schools in the week following Easter at Kamloops, having in view the advancement and care of the Indian people in these difficult times.

Assuring you of our keen appreciation of all your efforts on behalf of the Indian people and of your assistance at all times, I beg to remain with kind personal regards

Very sincerely yours,

W. M. Duke
Archbishop of Vancouver
Ottawa, March 27, 1940.

Dear Archbishop Duke,

I have for acknowledgment Your Grace's letter of March 20, in which you discuss the desirability of making provision in the future for the establishment of a junior high school section at the Indian Residential School, Mission, British Columbia.

I find it somewhat difficult to discuss your proposal in any practical or worthwhile sense, in view of existing conditions in the Dominion.

Our building program has been completely suspended during the last two years. It is my understanding that no provision has been made for the erection of any public buildings, other than those necessary for our war effort. Repairs, too, have been kept down to the lowest possible figure and there is, as you know, at this date an acute shortage of certain building materials, such as steel, tin, electrical equipment, roofing, etc.

It is gratifying to be able to report, however, that despite these restrictions a great deal of thought has been given to our Indian educational policy and to ways and means whereby it might be better adapted to the needs of the Indian population. We have now on the staff of this Department an official who prior to his appointment was in charge of the vocational section of the Balfour Technical School, Regina, Sask. This official is at present engaged in working out a course of vocational instruction which, it is hoped, will be incorporated in the courses of study provided at all Indian residential schools during the period that lies ahead of us. Lack of equipment and lack of suitable buildings are, of course, obstacles that still have to be overcome. In addition to this, a survey has recently been undertaken in the province of Ontario by a psychiatrist, working under the direction of the Ontario Department of Education. This official has made complete I. C. survey of practically all our Indian residential schools in Ontario, and we are awaiting the report with the utmost interest.

The Minister of the Department is very definitely of the opinion that the courses of study provided at Indian residential schools should become increasingly more practical and vocational in character. The success so far enjoyed by Indians who have taken what we usually term a straight academic course has been on the whole rather disappointing. Those who have returned to the reserves have returned, not to give leadership, but to become agitators in a very radical and destructive sense. Then, too, there is a tendency on the

Most Reverend K. M. Duke, D.D.,
Archbishop of Vancouver,
646 Richards Street,
Vancouver, B. C.
part of Indians who undertake this course to abandon it during the first or second year. Pupils who do this appear to go out into life with a disgruntled inferiority complex which is not at all helpful in improving living conditions on our Indian reserves.

You will be interested to learn that during the last two years I have been a member of the Canadian Legion National Educational Committee. It is the duty of this committee to provide vocational and academic courses for members of the Military Forces. I have been deeply interested in the large number of requests we have had from matriculants and from university graduates for practical courses such as auto mechanics, radio and telegraphy, electric welding, shorthand, typing, etc. It would appear that Canada has fallen far behind the European countries and even the United States insofar as adequate provision for vocational instruction is concerned.

I am afraid, however, that these thoughts I have been expressing will not prove very helpful to you, should you find it convenient to attend the conference at Kamloops, referred to in your communication, and it is certainly my hope that you will be able to attend the conference and let the principals and teachers who may be present have the benefit of your experience. My opinion at the moment is that, rather than organize high school or junior high school divisions at our regular residential schools, we should canvass the possibility of having a limited number of our brighter boys and girls attend classes at adjoining high schools, for example, the high school or technical school at Kamloops. These students, in my judgment, should remain at the school as grant-earning pupils, on the understanding that the Department would make a special grant to cover their tuition or instructional fees, at the adjoining high school or collegiate institute. This suggestion is not practical, of course, where there are no adjoining high schools. It has been attempted in the East, however, with a certain amount of success and would, in my judgment, be more successful in the West if Indian pupils were encouraged to take up vocational rather than academic courses. Here there is an adjoining high school, a few of the brighter boys and girls might be kept on at a number of our residential schools on the recommendation of the principal and provided with at least Grade 9 instruction, plus a certain amount of vocational instruction.

May I suggest to you that unless there are difficulties standing in the way, that I can not think of at the moment, Inspector Barry be invited to the Kamloops conference. As you know, Inspector Barry has had years of experience in the inspection of Indian residential schools. He has already met, and discussed vocational instruction with Mr. Doucet, of this Department, the official to whom I have already referred, and would, I feel confident, be in a position to guide and direct any discussion at the conference into worthwhile channels. It is scarcely necessary to add that
any resolutions passed at the conference or any suggestions in respect to ways and means whereby our educational program could be improved would be very sympathetically received and very carefully reviewed by the officials here. May I thank you very much indeed for your letter. Your interest in the education of the Indians and in ways and means whereby our program can be better adapted to their needs is very much appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Boey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I received your kind letter of March 27th regarding the possibility of beginning a Junior High School either at Mission City or Kamloops.

The matter came up at the meeting of the missionaries and principals of Indian Schools held at Kamloops on April 7th and 8th. The consensus of opinion was that Kamloops would be the better place and would be more central for our work on the Missions and the climate would also be more conducive to the health of the children.

We would appreciate first permission from the Government to allow eligible boys and girls to be transferred from other schools to this proposed school, which would simply be two additional rooms, one on the boys side and one on the girls side, and for which we would try to provide first-class teachers, one for boys and one for girls. Nothing radical is contemplated and if the permission to transfer eligible boys and girls was obtained, we would proceed slowly to perfect such a Junior High School.

Captain Barry was unable to be present at the Conference on account of sickness at that particular time, but the two days were profitably spent in convention in the interests of the Indian people.

We appreciate very much your sympathetic understanding of the work here at all times and for which we are very grateful.

With kind regards, I beg to remain

Very sincerely yours,

W. M. Duke
Archbishop of Vancouver

P.S. If we could have the permission shortly I could plan with the Fathers at Kamloops who could make a start on it next Fall.

Ottawa, June 9, 1942.

My dear Archbishop Duke:

I have for acknowledgment Your Grace's letter of June 1, in which you refer to the conference of missionaries and principals of Indian residential schools, held at Kamloops on April 7 and 8.

It is just possible that you may have learned that we have had under consideration for the last week or 10 days a request from the Department of Labour for the use of a limited number of our residential schools for the care and treatment of a group of Japanese citizens who appear to be suffering from tuberculosis and other physical disabilities. At the last conference called by the Government, at which all the churches were represented, it was agreed that the following schools might be placed at the disposal of the Labour Department: Edmonton (U.C.), Youville (R.C.), Elkhorn (C.F.) and either Kootenay or Cariboo (R.C.). This decision will, of course, tax to the utmost extent possible the available space at our other residential schools and in addition to any space that might be hurriedly provided. I have already discussed with Father O'Grady ways and means whereby the Kamloops School might take over a number of the pupils now enrolled at the Kootenay School.

You will readily appreciate that, in view of this decision, it is almost impossible for the Department to seriously consider provision for high school students at this particular time. I still think, however, that where the principals of our schools encounter a particularly bright and promising pupil, provision should be made whereby this boy might be permitted to remain two or three years longer at a residential school and be permitted to pursue his high school studies at the nearest high school or collegiate institute in the district. I am disposed to think that this is about all we can do during the war period.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you very heartily for your interest in this matter. The subject is one to which I have given a great deal of thought. Any additional suggestions that may occur to you will of course always be welcomed.

Yours sincerely,

E. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Canadian Globe Wood Washer quoted shall have a cylinder thirty (30) inches in diameter by inches in length outside measurements, and shall have one door, one compartment, with (galvanized) (brass) trim, (with) (without) safety devices.

**Cylinder**—Shall have heads, staves, and ribs of selected long leaf yellow pine.

Staves shall be cut from 1½-inch stock, rabbeted at heads and secured to the heads by wood dowels.

Heads shall be cut from 2-inch stock, and gained to receive lifting ribs.

Lifting ribs shall be cut from stock 3-inches by 5-inches. Ribs shall be rabbeted at heads. Three lifting ribs shall be provided.

Door closing ribs at the bottom and the top of the door opening shall be provided. Door closing ribs shall be cut from 3 by 3½-inch stock.

The door closing ribs at the bottom of the door opening shall be fitted with a stainless steel angle, and the door closing rib at the top of the door opening shall be fitted with a stainless steel channel to insure tight fitting doors.

The lifting ribs shall be secured to the cylinder head by means of a ½-inch galvanized iron bolt, extending through the cylinder hoop, ribs and into a recess in the head.

Door opening shall be 12-inches wide. Hinges shall be wide and well ribbed and shall rest on the cylinder hoops the full length of the hinge. Hinge battens shall be of brass. Cylinder shall be bandied with wide, heavy stainless steel hoops fastened to staves by Monel Metal screws. Where the door is 27-inches long or longer a hoop shall be fitted between the heads and shall completely encircle the cylinder except at the door opening.

Mechanite metal trunnions shall be securely attached to the cylinder heads.

**Tub**—Shall have heads and staves of clear or better fir.

Staves shall be cut from 1½-inch stock for sizes up to and including 36-inch length, and from 2-inch stock for sizes 48-inches in length and longer. Staves shall be tenoned, grooved and rabbeted to fit over heads to which they shall be secured by wooden dowels.

An upwardly sliding galvanized iron door shall operate in guides provided on adjustable, encircling bands or hoops, fitted with take-up bolts.

A gauge glass shall be mounted on the left tub head.

A sheet brass splash apron shall be provided at the bottom of the door opening to protect the staves.

**Frames**—Cast Mechanite metal frames of heavy design, rigidly bolted to the tub heads, shall support the weight of the cylinder and tub.

A heavy cast Mechanite metal upright bolted to the right-hand frame and tub head shall support the motor, motor bracket, and driving mechanism.

**Bearings**—The journals of the trunnions shall operate in cast-iron babbit lined bearings equipped with easily accessible lubricators. Journal bearings shall be supported by the cast Mechanite metal frames. Bearings for intermediate and drive shafts shall be of the roller type.
Water Inlet—A 2-inch water inlet connection shall be provided at the rear of the tub.

Steam Inlet—The admission of steam to the washer shall be through a steam spray flange located in the center back of the tub.

Outlet—The outlet valve shall be of the foot operated, positive closing type, 4-inches in diameter.

Safety Devices—Shall consist of a hook for holding the cylinder door open, and brass supply door on the tub door.

Trim—Galvanized trim shall include stainless steel hoops, galvanized hinges and galvanized iron latches on cylinder.

Brass trim shall include stainless steel hoops, brass hinges and brass latches on cylinder.

Drive—Cylinder shall be driven from the right-hand end by means of a combination multiple roller chain and spur gear drive. Gears shall be machined.

Guard—The drive shall be completely enclosed in sheet metal guards. The gear guard shall be full width, full diameter.

Electrical Equipment—Shall conform to applicable sections of standards of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

All wiring between electrical units mounted on the machine shall be properly installed in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

Motor—The drive motor shall be ball bearing, grease lubricated type, of ample capacity to operate the washer under continuous, full load operating conditions, without the motor temperature rise exceeding the limits allowed by N.E.M.A.

Controller—A controller in a sheet metal enclosure with a removable cover, shall be furnished mounted on the rear of the machine for control of the drive motor.

The controller shall incorporate a motor driven timer with magnetic contractors for reversing the drive motor, thermal type overload relay and pilot circuit fuses.

Timer shall insure that the number of cylinder revolutions between reversals are uniform with but slight difference in either direction of rotation.

Where needed controller shall incorporate protective resistance cut relays.

Interlock—The sliding tub door shall be electrically interlocked in such a manner that opening the tub door interrupts the electric service, causing the setting of the brake and stoppage of the cylinder and prevents further movement of same under power, except for inclining.

Operating Switch—Shall be mounted on the washer at a point easily accessible to the operator and shall incorporate push buttons necessary for obtaining normal machine functions and operations.

Brake—Shall consist of a spring set, electromechanically released, shoe type brake for stopping the cylinder movement and maintaining a cylinder at rest.

Wiring—Wiring in conduit shall be furnished connecting motor, operating switch, interlock switches and controller, with provision at controller for service connections. Service disconnect switch shall be furnished by customer.

Lubrication—Grease gun fittings shall be provided on all important bearings. Chain shall be lubricated by means of a wick oiler.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith quotations, covering different items of repairs and equipment, as stated in my estimates of last year. The delay in submitting these quotations is not at all to my liking, but can be very well understood, due to present restrictions on labour and material. I understand that the Department has allowed a sum for our expenditures on repairs and equipment and I would greatly appreciate your help in presenting these quotations to the Department as quickly as possible, so that there will not be a further delay. The enclosed quotations cover the following items:

A. Alterations to girls' recreation hall $175.00
B. Repairs to boys' building 955.00
C. Repairs to boiler 22.50
D. Repairs in laundry 39.50
E. Dairy equipment 175.00
F. Laundry equipment 720.00
G. Lumber for coal shed 150.00

A-B. The work on the boys' and girls' buildings is especially imperative, as it will relieve the crowded condition of the present time. During the past few years, we have been practically forced to take in more children, and in thus trying to co-operate with the Department and the Indians, we find the changes most urgent. Moreover, there are certain features of these buildings which need repair badly.

C. The brick-work on the front of the boiler needs to be renewed, to prevent the plate from bending. We have recently installed a large automatic stoker and the repairs to the brick will greatly assist the stoker's efficiency.

D. In order to keep the laundry from getting too hot and thereby cause hardship on the children and staff, I wish to replace the laundry stove, which is worn out, with a brick insulated stove. On this item and the preceding one, I have secured very good quotations.

E. The cream separator in the dairy is quite worn out and we need a new one. It has been the practise to supply milk from the Mission herd, to the School at about half of the commercial rate, thereby saving school funds and yet giving the children plenty of fresh milk daily. I would be glad therefore if the Department would assist in obtaining this item.

F. We have been trying to obtain a new washer in the laundry for years. Just when the way seemed clear to obtain it, some more pressing need arose and the washer had to wait. By now, both our washers are in poor shape. They are hard to obtain
but I have secured a quotation on one in the amount of $780.00. This sum, however, brings the total of the quotations to $468.00 more than the $1750.00, which the Department has allowed for repairs and equipment. Consequently, while it would be more helpful to have at least one new washer, that we could depend on, if the Department allows this extra amount, it might be possible, on the other hand, to have the present machines repaired to an extent, which would not exceed the grant. In other words, while I think it better to have a new washer for the laundry, I am prepared to obtain quotations on the repairing of the present washers up to an amount of approximately $232.00.

G. On authority of the Department, through the kind cooperation of the Commissioner, we have secured $160.00 worth of rough lumber to build a coal-shed. Quadruplicate copies of this bill will be submitted in due time. I wish to express my thanks to the Department for their promptitude in this matter.

I trust that you will find all the enclosed quotations in good order. It has been so difficult to obtain estimates due to shortages and yet I felt that I had to keep on trying under very difficult circumstances, because of the extreme urgency of our needs at the school. I could only obtain quotations from single firms and contractors, but in each case I was fortunate enough to make connections with reliable firms, who have previously done excellent work at the school. I feel sure that whatever expenditure is made will result in first-class work and materials.

Now that the quotations are all ready, after the trouble and delay of getting them, I am more than anxious that the work be completed and the equipment installed as soon as possible, so that we can benefit by them. I would be very pleased, therefore, if you would kindly see that these matters reach the Department at an early date. I feel sure that you will co-operate with me in this regard, after so many evidences of your kind interest in the school, in the past.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

March 1st, 1943.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I was unable to use the full allotment of money for repairs and equipment, allowed by the Department, to St. Mary's School, for the current fiscal year. Much needed repairs had to be postponed, because the contractor could not get the materials. This has been quite a disappointment to me as well as being a continuance of the conditions that I wished to remedy. However it could not be helped. The repairs were, namely, an addition to the boys' recreation hall and re-conditioning a large washer in the laundry.

Now, I have been faced with a new and immediate expense; a new drainage system has to be installed from the central building, to avoid the drainage backing up into the kitchen basement and manual training shop. The cost is estimated at $206.00. I know there is not much time left, but would it be possible to draw on the unused part of our allotment for this work. Otherwise it would entail a serious expense on the normal funds of the school, which are none too plentiful, right now. I can have the work and the bills put through this month, if you will advise me.

Kindly reply at once as I am worried about this condition and the expense involved in correcting it.

Dear Mr. Hoey;

I wish to acknowledge and thank you for your letter of March 5th, authorizing $208.00 towards the expense of building a drainage system. The need for this repair job came on so suddenly and I was so ill-prepared for it financially, that it is quite a relief to have the Department assume the expense.

You can readily believe how disappointed I was when I could not get the repairs completed that I had contemplated, and towards which the Department had kindly allowed $1750.00. The items which would have made up the unused portion of the grant were: an addition to the boys' recreation hall and the repair of a washer in the laundry. I had the estimates approved and then the washer people (the only firm out here that could make the repairs) turned their entire plant over to war work, and consequently could not do the work they quoted on. The carpenter tried his best, but could not get the materials for the repairs to the recreation hall. Thousands of feet of lumber float past our school every day, but there was none for us. However prospects look brighter this year, for certain supplies, and I am glad of it, because if the repairs were urgent last year, they are doubly so now.

We have a large enrollment this year and the children are well. We are busy putting in a very large garden in view of imminent shortages. Again thanking you for your kind letter.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Henry, O.M.I.

Mr. A.O.M. Daunt,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

For the past two years we have been trying to effect many necessary repairs and improvements at the St. Mary's school, without much success. This lack of success has been due to the scarcity of material and labour. Urgent repairs to the recreation hall, gymnasium, laundry and classrooms have been initiated; the work had to be dropped, because the contractors who had previously quoted on the work, did not get the materials nor the labour at the time when permission came through from the department at Ottawa.

This has been very disappointing to me and the department has also expressed regrets that the work they so kindly authorized could not have been completed. No blame can be attached in these matters and it may be said that such difficulties are to be expected during the time of war. However, I feel that the main trouble in having the repairs completed lies in the fact that no contractor cares to commit himself to a quotation, unless his figures can be accepted immediately. The same with materials. Several times I have located items and then when authority came to purchase them, they were gone. If the repairs were not urgent, I could reconcile myself to waiting until such time as things were normal. However you can readily understand that, in an institution like this, there are always certain repairs that cannot be put off. A number of such repairs have been completed and paid for out of the ordinary school funds, because they demanded immediate attention and the school funds were the only source of credit at hand.

In view of the fact, therefore, that certain items of repair and equipment are so necessary at the school, and that the ordinary channels of estimates, quotations and authorization from Ottawa, at the present time, handicap their completion, I would respectfully suggest and ask for a more efficacious procedure. If it could be arranged that, after my listing the more urgent items and their probable cost, authority would be given to go ahead with the repairs up to the limit of the amount listed. The accounts could then be sent to the department for payment, or paid by me and reimbursement applied for. This method would, I am sure enable many of the necessary repairs to be completed.

The following are the items and their probable cost:

A. Installation of wash basins in boys' and girls' dormitories, to accommodate about 20 each; four toilet bowls; labour and material ........... $400.00

B. Connecting hot water system to Preventorium; pipe, digging of trench and connections ........... $210.00

C. Repairs to radiators and replacements where necessary; materials and installation ........... $175.00
D. Extension to the boys' recreation hall. A very urgent matter that has been pending some time. I have located a mill that will supply the lumber and a contractor to supply the labour. This work was planned for last year but the contractor could not get material. Material and labour for the above $1100.00

E. Manual training lumber $180.00

F. Repairs to heating system in men's building $205.00

G. Reshingling and painting roof of boys' classroom $195.00

H. Fireproof roofing, either iron or patent, for roof of laundry around the smoke stack $80.00

I. Lumber for repairs to dairy, barn and bull-pen $450.00

I submit the above items for the approval of the Department. Your records will show that during the past two years the Department authorized generous amounts for these and similar repairs, but the work could not be done at the time. I hope that, with the kind cooperation of the Department, this work may now be done, in the interests of the school and the welfare of the Indian children.

In many of the above cases, I have anticipated using reconditioned material, for economical reasons and also because it is the only way to procure it. I would like to assure you and the Department, that if they authorize the work as listed above, which is so necessary, a very conscientious effort will be made not only to have the work done satisfactorily, but also as economically as possible. I would be very grateful if you would forward my request to the Department as soon as possible. Just this morning, while phoning to get prices on shingles, the mill told me that they had fairly large stocks on hand this week, but could not say what stock they would have next week. I mention this to show how conditions are and how advantageous it would be if I had the authorization requested in this letter.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Ottawa, Ontario.

October 19th, 1943.

Mr. Daunt,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I am giving herewith a statement of the repairs and expenditures, contemplated as a result of the Department's kind authorization of $1350.00 in this regard.

A. Shingling and repairing roofs of boys' classroom building and part of the laundry. $295.00

B. Painting of entire boys' classroom building; interior of staff building; laundry roof; chicken-house roof and walls; dairy; part of junior classroom and several rooms in administration building. Labour and materials $398.00

C. Lumber for dairy barn floor and partition; bullpen; partitions in girls' dormitories; chicken house; repairs to porch in men's building; building of creamery in kitchen basement; partitions in boys' dormitory toilets; bins and cupboards in kitchen; repairs to roof of dairy; one set of barn doors. Materials only $325.00

D. Installation of heating system in men's staff building, consisting of hot air furnace, flues, and 7 outlets. Labour and materials $205.00

E. Addition to toilet and wash facilities in boys' and girls' dormitories; 8 toilet bowls; 3 large wash basins; complete connections; Labour and materials $315.00

Some of the work has already been completed, while other parts are in progress. The total of these amounts exceed the Departmental authorization of $1350.00 and this difference will either be taken out of school funds or the work limited. Already a substantial reduction has been made in the proposed toilet installations, by arranging to have the wash basins made up locally instead of purchasing from the trade. Full accounts in detail will be forwarded to your office, when the work has been satisfactorily completed.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am listing below several items of athletic and sporting equipment, which are needed for the coming year at the St. Mary's Indian Residential school. I understand that the Department is pleased to supply such on request.

8 soccer footballs #5 good quality.
2 Canadian rugby balls "
12 Outseam softballs "
4 Padded tumbling mats 12' long.

As part of the health and recreational program of the school, athletics are promoted. We have developed two outstanding soccer teams, senior and junior, which have competed successfully with district high schools.

Last year we had one team of gymnasts competing in Vancouver for the Pro-Rec; this year we have three teams going in on the 25th of April. Moreover they will take part in the Provincial Recreation display, which is to be staged at the Forum on that date. So far we have made all our own equipment, horses, parallel bars, springboards etc. The mats are something we cannot make however. Mr. Matheson, Provincial Director of the Pro-Rec, is very enthusiastic about the boys work, and I feel that we owe him a deep debt of gratitude for the interest he has shown. It would be very encouraging for him as well as for myself if the Department would kindly supply the mats. The work we have started is important and has possibilities of great development as part of the Canada National Fitness Campaign, which is now so much to the fore.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I beg to forward you herewith, a request received from Reverend A.H. Fleury, Principal of St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, for the following athletic and sporting equipment:

- 8 soccer footballs #5 good quality.
- 2 Canadian rugby balls
- 12 Cutseam softballs

October 24th, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

The Reverend Principal of St. Mary's Indian Residential School, is in receipt of a letter from the Department, a copy of which I understand is in your possession, informing him that an amount of $1,000.00 may be made available for repairs and equipment at St. Mary's Indian Residential School, for the present year.

I am enclosing a letter received today, from the Reverend Principal, requesting repairs and installations which he wishes to undertake against the above amount, and totalling $1,040.00.

As materials and labour are very difficult to arrange, he requests that permission be given him to proceed with this work up to a given amount, and on its completion purchase orders to cover will be applied for to cover the accounts.

With the scarcity of materials, it will be necessary to shop around, and, therefore, almost impossible to take out purchase orders in the first instance.

I would, therefore, recommend that his request be granted, and that authority be given to undertake the work, as requested in his letter.

A.G.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith quotation of Mr. W. Swan on the construction and equipping of a toilet room as an addition to the girls' building. I need hardly say how necessary this addition is, as it has been the subject of correspondence for some time. I feel very fortunate in having Mr. Swan ready to do the work as he has always proven himself to be an honest and reliable contractor.

His quotation is very reasonable. You will note that the amount is $810.00. This amount added to the $235.00 already allocated towards the purchase of a potato peeler (letter of November 14th) exceeds by $45.00 the amount authorized by the Department, which was $1000.00. We are prepared to pay the extra $45.00, if the Department cannot see their way to do so.

This proposed construction therefore, uses up all the money allotted, so the other repairs etc. will have to wait, although they too are needed urgently. I had not thought the toilet addition would be so costly; apparently I had based my figures on a pre-war basis. However I am very glad that at last this long-deferred improvement will be made. It is of the utmost importance that we receive the authorization of the Department as quickly as possible. Therefore I ask your kind co-operation in expediting the matter.

Very sincerely,

Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Could you please advise me as to what amount has been allowed by the Department for repairs and equipment at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School for the current year.

In my estimates for this year, I had requested various repairs to buildings, which were in poor condition. The amount totalled $2150.00. I did not list any equipment, which was greatly needed, because the estimates were compiled last year, and with the war still on, I had given up hope of obtaining what was needed until hostilities ceased. The other day our cold storage and refrigeration system finally gave up the ghost. It was a second-hand system, installed about twelve years ago by Father Gillen. We had been nursing it along for the past years, but now after its recent breakdown, we have been advised that it is in hopeless condition. You can well appreciate the difficulties this condition has imposed upon the school. It is absolutely necessary that we have proper facilities for storing our large quantities of meat, dairy produce etc. I have been very fortunate in securing the necessary replacements, subject to authorization by the Department. I am today forwarding quotations for such, in the amount of $695.00, to Mr. Daunt. It is very important that this matter be given favorable and speedy consideration by the Department, firstly, because we cannot get along without a cold storage system and secondly, because the supplier cannot guarantee holding it for us too long. The price is very low and the equipment extremely sound and efficient. Please do all you can to help me in this matter.
Last year the Department placed an order for a potato peeler for the school, but as delivery could not be made, the order was cancelled. We still need this equipment quite urgently and I have been advised by the manufacturers that they are now in a position to supply one to us. I intend to apply for this through Mr. Daunt, but thought it advisable to advise you of the circumstances.

I am at present trying to secure quotations for the repairing of certain floor areas in the school. It has been quite difficult to obtain materials for this work, but I am glad to say that I have at last contacted a firm, the Tremco Co., who distribute a mastic preparation, which is ideal for our purpose. This item of repairs was listed on our estimates of last year. Another item, namely, painting of some buildings, is also in process of quotation and the results will be forwarded within a few days.

I trust that you will understand why there is a variance between our estimates of last year and the actual quotations now being submitted. It was impossible to secure equipment last year, so we planned repairs, for which we judged the materials might be more obtainable. Now the situation is almost reversed; lumber is at a premium, while equipment is starting to come on the market. To climax it all, our cold storage system is completely gone and the old potato peeler likewise. Consequently we are in urgent need of the pieces of equipment and plan to carry out also the item of repairs to the floors and the painting. Just how far we will be able to go in this plan depends on the Departmental allowance, that has been granted.

Will you kindly advise me of our position in this regard.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.
Ottawa, 26th September, 1945.
