Dear Mr. Daunt;

I am enclosing herewith four copies of quotation, submitted by W.J. Windebank of Mission, B.C., who is the representative of the Western Agencies of Vancouver, dealers in refrigeration equipment.

Our cold storage and refrigeration system has completely broken down at the school. It is an old system, installed second-hand many years ago by Father Gillen. For a long time it has given us much trouble, but we managed to keep it going. The last break was very serious and we have been advised that it is impossible to repair it. I do not need to tell you of the urgency of this matter. We have large quantities of food, such as meat, dairy produce etc., to be conserved and protected and without a cold storage system we are sadly handicapped. Because of our extreme need and by a very fortunate chance, I have secured a quotation for immediate installation, on a very sound and economical system. The price is $695.00 installed. Please do your utmost to bring this matter to the attention of the Department as our need is great and the equipment cannot be reserved for us too long. Urgency is of the utmost importance in this matter.

I will be writing you again in a few days with regard to other items of repairs and equipment for the current year. I wished, however to get this present item through as quickly as possible, as it is a special emergency.

Very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Under date of October 3rd, 1945, the Department issued a purchase order #5768 to W.J. Windebank of Mission, B.C., for the installation of refrigerating equipment at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School. The cost, as originally quoted by the supplier was to be $695.00. I was in Ottawa while this equipment was being installed and a few days before leaving, I was advised from the School, that due to an error, certain essential parts of the kitchen refrigerator had not been allowed on the quotation or purchase order. I could not get in immediate touch with you to remedy this emergency, as you were out of town. I advised the supplier by wire to install what was necessary as it was the only thing to do.

The extra installation, which consists of an ice-making machine, valves and fittings amounts to $134.70, making a total for the whole refrigerating system of $829.70. It is unfortunate, of course, that this was not included in the original quotation and purchase order. However in view of the circumstances, I would ask you to kindly arrange to take care of this extra amount. In case another purchase order is required the extra items are as follows:
1- Ice making coil $65.00; 1- Temperature valve $21.60;
1- Expansion Valve $19.75; 1- Check valve $5.00;
Labour of installation complete with fittings, methyl chloride $23.35. Total $134.70.

I mentioned to you, while I was in Ottawa, that we had great need of an automatic coal-feeding system for our kitchen range. You suggested that quite probably this could be purchased out of the grant for repairs, as long as the total cost did not exceed $500.00. I have been
very fortunate in securing an excellent automatic feeder, completely installed at a total cost of $395.00. The description of this feeder is as follows:

1- L20 Iron Fireman Stoker, completely installed with controls $395.00.

Would you please advise as to what I should do to have this item paid for out of the grant for repairs. The supplier is W.J. Windebank, Mission, B.C.

I would be very pleased if you reply to this letter as soon as possible, as I am anxious to have these bills paid. In each case the work has been all completed and is giving entire satisfaction. Very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Gillett;

As I mentioned in my letter dated July 20th, many of the repairs and improvements, planned for this year, have had to be postponed as we are unable to get materials. However I was fortunate enough to secure quotations on the painting and repairing of our main building. This building is badly in need of painting as the stucco walls are beginning to crack, due to the lack of a protecting coating. The slate roof is in poor condition and gives a very shabby appearance to the building.

I have secured two quotations as enclosed. The one of M.A. Girard and Sons seems quite high, whereas the other of Webster Bros. appears to be very reasonable. Moreover they live in this district and have a good reputation as painting contractors.

I would be very pleased if you would take the necessary steps to have this work completed out of the Departmental allotment for the current year for St. Mary's School.

There are several other badly needed repairs in regard to which I will write you later. There is also the possibility that the materials which are at present holding up work, listed on last years estimates, may be procurable within a few months.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: St. Mary's Indian Residential School,
Mission, British Columbia.

The Principal of the above mentioned school reports that the building is badly in need of painting as the stucco walls are beginning to crack, due to the lack of a protecting coating. The slate roof is also in poor condition. The Indian Commissioner agrees with the Principal and he has submitted quotations from Webster Brothers, Abbotsford, British Columbia and from M.A. Girard and Sons, New Westminster, British Columbia. The quotations of Webster Brothers for material and labour is $1065.00 and is much less than the quotation received from the other firm. The Indian Commissioner recommends the acceptance of the quotation received from Webster Brothers and I would appreciate it if the Minister would give his approval so that the work may be done in the near future.

This is a church-owned school and funds were provided in the current year's appropriation.

I enclose for your information the quotations mentioned above.
